OTTAWA, 6th March, 1902

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of the 1st instant in further reference to the condition of Mary Seme, whom you state is dying of consumption; and in reply I beg to inform you that the Department has so far been unable to locate her father, Joseph Seme and that the Postmaster at Pembroke reports that letters addressed to him there are still uncalled for.

The Department regrets that it has been unsuccessful in its efforts to reach this Indian and it considers that you have done everything possible to acquaint Seme with his daughter's condition.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLEAN

Secretary

Geo. Ley, King, Esq.,
Principal,
Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste Marie,
Ont.

Sir,

Referring to previous correspondence in the case of Mary Semo, I beg to inform you that the Principal of the Shingwauk Home advised the Department yesterday of this girl's death. Sir,

I desire the department's sanction to permit a few of the pupils of the Shingwauk and Nancoway homes (about 8 or 10) who have not been home for two years or more, one month's term of absence during the coming vacation, upon the following conditions viz:

Immediate

I beg to report that on the 17th instant a man named John Hare (alias) but not yet so identified was seen by an Indian woman of Duncan deliberately carried away and abducted from the Shingwauk Home two of our Indian girls namely Lydia Paine and Jennie Clark both under sixteen years of age. The girls were located within twenty minutes from their hiding place. Search parties were sent out and the police on both sides of the river notified and every possible means of discovery employed.

It was not until 4 P.M. the following day however that the man together with the girls were caught in the American soil.

The girls are again in the hands of the Indians and the man is held by the American authorities on any charge of abducting the girls for immoral purposes—spending extramarital.

Hague connected.

Ottawa, 24th June, 1902.

Sir,-

I enclose copy of a letter from the Principal of the Wawanosh Home at Sault Ste. Marie, from which it will be seen that two Indian girls attending the Home were abducted by a man named Flaxon for immoral purposes.

The girls have been returned to the Home and Flaxon has been remanded until this morning.

This Department is desirous that the necessary action should be taken in the matter by your Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

The Acting Deputy Minister of Justice, Ottawa.
King v Jonathan Flaxon.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant (Ref 152067), I have the honour to state that having communicated with our agent in the matter, he telegraphs me as follows:

"Flaxon in custody police American Sault. State prosecutor will return in two or three days. Until then police will hold, when prisoner can be remanded as desired. Will give matter best attention. John Mackay."

I am

Your obedient servant

Acting D.M.J.

The Secretary
Indian Department.
A. Power, Esq., K.C.,
Acting D'y Minister of Justice,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

As wired you I attended at the American Sault upon receipt of your telegram and found Jonathan Flaxton in the hands of the police there. The State Prosecutor was absent and pending his return nothing could be done. He is expected in a day or two. The Chief Police undertook to retain the prisoner until the return of the State Prosecutor. We apprehend no difficulty in obtaining the remand required. I will be notified when the matter can be taken up and will attend and endeavor to see done what may be necessary and shall then further advise.

From Mr. King, the Principal of the Wawanosh Home, I have obtained the statement of facts following: Flaxton called at the Home some days prior to the abduction; with him was a woman, said to be his wife, and two children. He wanted the children taken into the Home. Flaxton is white; the children showed no Indian blood and were denied admission. Flaxton claimed to be an uncle of the two girls whom he afterwards abducted. By marriage it is possible he may be their uncle but this supposition is improbable. Immediately after for some days Flaxton was seen about the premises in the vicinity of the Home. It is supposed his object was to get the girls away to Duluth for immoral purposes. Both girls are between fifteen and sixteen years. The final—and probably correct—story told by the girls is to the effect that Flaxton told them to come with him.
and he would look after them, dress them and take care of them in future. The day they went away he induced them to go with him into the adjoining woodland where they were hidden until dark; thence they proceeded along the C.P. Railway track—which lies adjacent—and so across the International Railway bridge to the American Sault. Flaxton had been employed as a brakeman on the Algoma Central Railway. This would facilitate the unquestioned crossing the Railway bridge and would make him familiar with the railway yards at the American Sault where he took the girls and kept them over night in a box car. To one of the girls he gave $35. in cash saying it was to buy clothes. In the morning dresses were bought and it is understood Flaxton was heading for the train when apprehended. The girls were recognized by one of the Indian boys detailed to watch. With the boy the girls returned to the Home. At first they were disposed to tell everything but the truth. Persistent enquiry finally elicited the story as above and this considered by Mr. King to be true. Apart from the abduction, no harm would appear to have happened the girls.

To prevent a repetition of similar exploits, Mr. King is anxious to have an example made. From the interference of relatives and others Mr. King claims to have much to contend with and he realized that were anything such as this attempted abduction permitted with impunity the result would be little short of deplorable.

We have written Mr. King impressing the importance of being prepared with conclusive evidence of the age of the girls, that is, of being able to establish the age as under
sixteen years. As soon as we hear we will report further.

Yours &c,

Copy.

[Signature]

Re Jonathan Flaxton.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose you herewith copy of a letter received from our agent in connection with this matter, for your information. Subsequent to the date of that letter our agent writes to say that he has been keeping in touch with the American authorities with respect to the charge against this man. The prisoner having been taken in charge by the United States marshal consented to return to Canada waiving further extradition proceedings. He was brought across to Sault Ste Marie and lodged in the district jail, where he is now confined. The district crown attorney has taken hold of the matter having received instructions to do so from the Deputy Attorney General of Ontario. Do you still desire our agent to appear in the matter? If so, please advise me at the earliest possible moment.

I am

Your obedient servant

Acting D.M.J.

The Secretary
Indian Department.

Oct. 1st./'02

Sir:

We are in great difficulty regarding the obtaining of necessary fuel for the heating of our Indian Homes during the rapidly approaching winter.

It is impossible to obtain coal here at any price, and wood on the Shingwauk property became exhausted many years ago.

In addition to the heating of outside buildings, such as the School house, Laundry, and Trade shops we have three large coal furnaces in the main building to feed, which however economically managed consumes not less than sixty five tons of hard coal each winter.

No other course suggests itself but to convert the coal furnaces into wood furnaces by obtaining from the manufacturers wood grates, dampers etc., and to import at once before the close of navigation hardwood from St. Joseph's Island. This however will prove a costly way of heating for it will I presume take at least two cords of hardwood to equal one ton of anthracite coal.

But we have no alternative.

We are already six hundred dollars in debt and it is simply impossible to incur this increased and unlooked for expenditure with-
out some assistance from the Department.

I earnestly ask the Department therefore to assist us in our
dilemma to the extent of five hundred dollars which sum I would re-
spectfully suggest might fairly and justly be a charge on those Bands
from which our pupils are drawn; since it is solely for their children's
benefit the assistance is asked.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Principal
My dear Sir,

I venture to hope that the Department of Indian Affairs may see its way to grant a favourable reply to Mr. King's appeal. The crisis is a real one. Owing to the scarcity of coal and the high rate being charged for both coal and wood, we do not see our way through the task of providing fuel for our women during the coming winter. Yet to disband our forces at such a season of the year would be a most distressing course. Such considerations seem fully to justify an appeal for special aid. I trust it may be granted.

Believe me,

Faithfully yours,

George A. Agawa

Ottawa, 6th October, 1902.

Memorandum.

The Acting Secretary:

His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma forwards under cover of a letter dated the 3rd instant an application from Mr. King, Principal of the Shingwauk Home for a grant of $500.00 to assist the school in converting the coal furnaces into wood furnaces.

This application is made owing to the impossibility of obtaining hard coal at Sault Ste. Marie for the winter's supply. Mr. King suggests that this amount might be charged against the bands from whom their pupils are drawn since it is solely for their benefit.

I do not think that it would be a fair charge to make against the Indians as they are in no way responsible for the coal famine. The Department has no funds at present available to which such a contribution could be properly charged and it seems to me that it would be incurring great expense to change the furnaces for one winter. It would be much cheaper to revert to the old system of heating by stoves, however as the matter stands it is one for the consideration of the Department. If they cannot get coal or proper appliances to burn wood the school will most likely have to be closed for the winter as the Institution has no funds of its own to make the suggested change, in fact it is some $600.00 in debt at present and the extra charge of fuel will increase their liabilities. This is the first application of the kind received and if it were granted there would no doubt be many others as all the Indian schools would find themselves in a similar dilemma.

MEMO.

The admission of children to Algoma Indians only, our doors are just as wide open to the Indian children from all over the Eastern Provinces and some are admitted solely at the Department's request. Nor are we like other schools, notably those in the North West, constantly in receipt of grants from the Department outside of per capita grant allowance.

I think, My Lord, that the Department might in justice recognize these facts and afford us some assistance in our present need.

Your Lordship is fully aware that it is simply impossible to solve the present difficulty unaided, and like various other charitable institutions throughout the country who are being assisted by the Municipalities, we must, if we are to keep our doors open this winter also receive a helping hand. My Lord:

I have yours of the 16th inst. enclosing the Department's letter #162067—5 dated Oct. 5th, in reply to mine of the 3rd, asking for assistance towards this winter's supply of fuel.

I regret my letter should have been misinterpreted. The grant of $500 asked for was not for the purpose of converting our coal furnaces into wood furnaces. A sum of less than $50 would probably cover such cost of alteration. The assistance is asked however to meet the unexpected and largely increased cost of fuel due to the recent coal strike and our inability to obtain either hard or soft coal, and thus being driven as a result, to import hard dry wood and which for reasons stated in my previous letter will prove a costly mode of heating compared with former years.

Weighted down as we are at the present time with a deficit of some $600 incurred in our maintenance account, I cannot see how we can possibly incur such increased liability, without some assistance from the Department.

The sixty or seventy children now in the home are not less the Department's wards than ours. We do not restrict

I cannot do better than read the enclosed letters to you who last before the Department. EXTRACT from the editorial comment of "Toronto Saturday Night"
27th September, 1902.

Speaking of national beggars the "Canadian Gazette" London, Eng., says: "The Rev. H.W. Gibbon Stocken, C.M.S., Hon. Canon and Rural Dean of Calgary, is the latest Canadian clerical mendicant. He has this week issued through the English press an appeal for £1,500 in connection with the removal to a more desirable locality of schools established among the Blackfoot Indians in the diocese of Calgary. He explains that the Canadian Government has promised £500, which we hope will be considerably increased but in the meantime he asks the British public to put both hands in its pockets". I have frequently denounced this sort of thing, the last clerical mendicant who put Canada to shame having hailed from Montreal, and I am sure that all Canadians agree with the "Gazette" that this sort of thing is most distasteful to Canadian self-respect and most unfair to the many English institutions and causes which should have a first claim upon the English charitable. The writer admits that in the early days of Canadian settlement it was inevitable that these appeals should have been made, "but" he adds "to-day Canada is rich beyond the most sanguine expectations of her early days. She is not alone rich; she has assumed the dignity of matronhood, and among the charges which have thus fallen upon her ample revenues is that of her Indian citizens and fellow-subjects. How can the English public bring itself to believe that Canada is, at this harvest time, overflowing with prosperity when at the same moment Canadian clerics encroach upon English munificence for the religious education and support of a few Indian children in the heart of the very country which is now realizing such abundant wealth?" In conclusion the "Gazette" very properly declares, "The whole proceeding is unreasonable and undignified to the last degree, and
we would appeal to the many leaders of Canadian opinion who
we know sympathize with our view, to echo this protest among
those to whom Canon Gibbon Stocken and other Canadian religious
workers should make their first and last appeal. When, oh when
will officious people cease humiliating Canadians abroad by
appealing to the English purse in aid of patriotic funds, fire
sufferers, missions, church funds, and all sorts of things which
if we cannot ourselves supply, we certainly ought not to have
given to us. We boast that the West is a granary bursting
with riches and yet it appears that there is a wail going up

MEMORANDUM: In re the Shingwauk and Vermilion Industrial Schools for Indian Children at Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

1. The schools were established as a private venture by the Rev. L. F. Wilson in 1875.

2. The government gave them an annual per capita grant of $60.

3. At the outset great interest was shown in the schools by the general public; and money towards their support was obtained with comparative ease. After a time however the interest waned, and in 1890, harassed and broken down with the financial strain of his work, Mr. Wilson abandoned the schools, and the Church of England in Algoma, to prevent their being closed, became responsible for them.

4. From the beginning of her responsibility the church had a hard struggle to maintain the work. In addition to the grant of $60, a sum of $75, has had to be provided each year for each child admitted to the schools. The average number of pupils being 65 an aggregate of nearly $5000, has been provided annually from outside sources.

5. Year by year it becomes increasingly difficult to obtain money. General interest has slackened and missionary contributions have multiplied. As a result our income has been inadequate even for maintenance apart from special expenditure as the following statement shows.
Receipts:

Government Grants: $2400

Contributions from outside sources:

Total Expenditure: $10975.56

6. This deficiency has been made up in part by an annual grant of about $1000 from the Mission Fund of Algoma. But this fund was created for other purposes and cannot much longer bear the strain thus put upon it. Even with this grant from the Mission Fund a deficit on account of maintenance has been gradually accumulating which amounted on May 1st to $660.00. This amount is due on current accounts to business men in small amounts.

7. Through lack of means we have never been able to admit the full number of pupils permitted us by the government, viz 150, our average number being 65. At present we have only 50. Ten applications for admission have been refused during the past year.

8. Because of a supposed difference in the cost of maintaining the small R.C. Marie School, like the three other Industrial Schools of Ontario, has received a grant of only $30 per capita, one half the amount paid to similar schools west of Ontario, which receive from $110 to $140 per capita. Yet the difference in the cost of maintenance, instead of being as one to two, is all things considered, comparatively slight.

9. Owing to the state of our finances our school property has seriously deteriorated and need extensive repair. While a sum of $2000 at least is required to restore our exhausted stock and equipment.

In view of the above facts, the utter inadequacy of the per capita grant, the increasing difficulty of obtaining aid from outside, the crippled condition of our work generally and the heavy deficit now facing us; we deem it essential to the proper maintenance, if not the very existence of our work, that the government per capita grant should be increased to $100 at least. Even that would leave us some $3500 to collect annually from outside sources, for ordinary maintenance, apart from the cost of repairs and the payment of our deficit.

At the beginning of April last, with the Bishop of Ottawa and others, I had the privilege of an interview with you upon the subject of the Indian Homes at Sainte-Marie.

The object of this interview, as you will remember, was to secure from the Government, through your interest as Acting Minister of the Interior, an increase in the per capita grant of $60, which is utterly inadequate for the maintenance of our work.

We explained that this sum ($60), which is only one half the amount given to similar Industrial Schools in the West, leaves us much more to be provided by us; and that we find it increasingly difficult to obtain the voluntary aid we need to supplement the grant.

At the time of our interview a deficit of $960 had, in consequence of the facts mentioned above, accrued upon our operations.

For the Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs.

In compliance with instructions contained in your letter to me of the 31st ultimo, I proceeded to Sault Ste. Marie on the 1st instant to make an examination of the Shingwauk Institution at that place.

The Principal of the Institution was absent on my arrival so that I did not commence my duties till the 3rd instant when I began an examination of the accounts which I found to be kept in a very careful and satisfactory manner. The books have been audited annually by officers appointed for the purpose, the last audit having been made in February last by His Honour, Judge Johnston and A.W. Roberts, Esquire, Manager of the Bank of Commerce, which covered the year ended the 31st December, 1902; and it is shown that the Institution had at that time a deficit of $600.01; this did not occur altogether during that year, but has been gradually accumulating since 1894, at which time it was $189.41.

The books are written up to 30th September and at that date show the amount of debts owing to be $5,617.39 and available assets from which to pay the same $1,064.41 leaving a shortage of $1,552.98

I append a list of the creditors with detailed accounts from which it will be seen that Messrs. W.H. Plummer & Co. are the largest, their account amounting to $1,617.83. That firm furnished nearly all the supplies in the way of staples, and has carried the deficit since it commenced. I have examined these accounts for some years back and the goods that have been supplied are of the same class as those named in the detailed accounts attached. I have noticed in going through the accounts that

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Supt. General of I.A.

I beg to transmit herewith a report by Mr. R.G. Dalton of the Office upon the Shingwauk Home. The report is short and to the point, and it is only necessary to read it to obtain a clear idea as to the position which this school now occupies financially. To my mind the report shows that the Institution has been carefully managed and that the present deficit has not accrued owing to extravagant management. In view of this fact, and taking into consideration the attitude of the Department in the past with reference to the frequent deficits which have arisen at Industrial Schools in Manitoba and the North West Territories (which I am bound to say have not always been incurred under such unavoidable circumstances) I would recommend that the Department come to the assistance of the Shingwauk Home. To refuse to do so at this juncture would mean the closing of the school. I am of the opinion that the present per capita grant paid in Ontario is not sufficiently large to meet the cost of conducting these schools. The question of increasing this per capita grant was taken up last year, but no decision was arrived at. It is my object, therefore, to recommend action by which the present stringency may be relieved without increasing the estimates of the Department.

I would propose to pay the deficit in two instalments: one on the 1st. of January, proximo, the other on the 1st. of July, if the supply fund is at that time available, if not, as soon after as possible. In addition to this I would propose to provide gradually the material required to place the building in a fair state of repair. When this is accomplished and when the boiler...
boiler and engine are removed a saving of fuel will, I am sure, ensue. The expenditure that I propose by this recommendation will not be subject to any supplementary vote; it can be made from the current appropriations without detriment to our present obligations. By thus dealing with the Shingwauk Home we will not be according it better treatment than the Mount Elgin Institute. We have practically assisted that Institution in meeting its obligations by very considerable grants for re-building, and improving its equipments.

The current year's estimates contain an item of $2,500 an additional grant to the Mount Elgin Institute for this purpose. Up to the present time the Shingwauk Home has received no such assistance.

Sir,

After some difficulty and much delay I succeeded on the 1st of December last in obtaining the services of an expert machinist and boiler maker, Mr. John Scott, to examine the Shingwauk Boiler and Engine in accordance with the Department's instructions to me under date of the 30th November.

Mr. Scott, after a thorough examination informs me that the Boiler and Engine, both second hand when purchased for the school twenty years ago, are now completely worn out and that he found the Boiler so thin in places that a punch could easily have been driven through by hand.

He considers that to attempt any repairs would be a waste of money and that the Boiler and Engine should be discarded as soon as possible and in any case ought not to be used for more than three months longer and at a pressure not exceeding 40%.

Mr. Scott is of opinion that a 10 H.P. Gasoline Engine, costing with all necessary fixtures somewhere about $500 would do the pumping, run our circular saw and planing mill equally as well as a steam power and would consume less than half the fuel. He points out that a Gasoline engine develops full power immediately and as soon as the work is done can be shut down and all expense ceases—a great advantage and saving of fuel where, as in our case, an engine is required for a short time two or three times a week.

Mr. Scott estimates the value of the old Boiler and engine at $50 for scrap iron. A sum therefore of about $450 would be required to install a Gasoline Engine and we are, as the Department is aware, totally unable to face such an expenditure and can only rely upon the Department's generosity to aid us in our dilemma.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir:

We have yours of the 9th inst., to hand re engine, and believe we are in a position to supply you with an engine that will meet your requirements in every particular. We have placed a great number of our engines for work similar to that which you wish to use it for, in fact we make a specialty of engines for this purpose. Only about 10 days ago we took an order from the Mount Elgin Industrial Indian School, which is situated at Muncey, for an 18 F.P. portable engine to use in connection with the Institute. They will use it much for the same purpose that you require, only they possibly require a little heavier power, as they want to use it to run some heavy machinery in connection with their laundry as well as to do work in connection with their farm.

We are enclosing you a description of our engine, and also a cut of same. We would ask you to note carefully in this description the many points of superiority which we have over engines of other makes. One point in particular to which we would call your attention to, is the question of the governor of our engine, in that we are able to change the speed of the engine by the governor while the engine is running and doing work; this is an important feature, especially in your case, as we note that you want to run a number of different pieces of machinery, and with other makes of engines when you change from one piece to the other, it would necessitate the change of the speed of your engine, as we have described in our description, this would occasion much fruitless labor in obtaining the right speed. While with our engine the speed can be changed at will while the engine is in motion, and when you attach it to a new piece of machinery, you simply have to screw either up or down on your governor button until you arrive at the right speed. This is a great improvement on a gasoline engine, and is in fact a deciding point with a great many purchasers in favor of our engine.

We guarantee our engines in every respect, in fact we have the largest plant in Canada devoted entirely to the manufacture of gas and gasoline engines, and as the result, we have to turn out a line of goods that will meet with the approval of the public, if it were otherwise, we would in a short time, not be able to find a market for our goods, nor manufacturing any other line, and would be compelled to go out of business.

When we place an engine with a customer we have as much, if not more interest in seeing that it gives satisfaction, it is not a question of one sale or one order, but we hope that every engine that we place, especially at a central point, such as your School, that will lead to many more orders from the same District.
Our new illustrated catalogue is in the hands of the printers, and as it will not be out for a few days, we regret we are not able to give you more complete information. We are, however, sending you a few testimonials, as we find a great many customers would rather have the opinion of some party who has used the engine as it gives possibly more correct ideas of what the engine will actually do.

The price of our 10 H.P. engine is $375 cash or $405 on time. The price of our 12 H.P. engine is $425 cash or $465 on time. In regard to the price, we do not claim that we sell at as low figures as possibly some other manufacturers do, but we do claim to give better value for the money than any other make that is in the market today. The question with the Mount Elgin Institution was not in price, but of purchasing an engine that would be thoroughly reliable in every respect, and while they could have purchased engines at a lower rate than ours, they decided in favor of our engine. This price includes all the necessary equipments for the engine, including batteries, gasoline and water tank, exhaust pipe and mufflers, and all the necessary connections ready to operate the engine. This price is F.O.B. Toronto Junction, and the freight would simply be a matter of so many hundred from here to Sault Ste Marie. The engine will weigh in the neighborhood of a ton and a half.

We believe, as you will note from the testimonials that our customers who have used our engines find that gasoline is much more economical than steam, in fact, if you had a gasoline engine say 10 H.P. capacity, when you are running it say on a pump and only require 2 or 3 H.P. to run it, you could operate it just as cheaply as you could a 2 H.P. engine, while with a steam engine there would be very little difference in the cost, whether you operate it at full capacity or at half. Further, with a gasoline engine, it does not require the services of a man to look after it as when once the engine is started, it does not require any attention, while with a steam engine, it is necessary to have some person giving constant attention to it.

Speaking generally of the cost of steam and gasoline, we find in anything up to a 25 H.P. that gasoline, under all circumstances, is more economical than steam. We have even placed gasoline engines in planing mills and saw mills, where the fuel for a steam engine practically amounts to nothing, but the parties have installed gasoline simply because it was much more convenient to get up power in a few seconds, and when they do not require the power, the engine can be stopped immediately. Also gasoline has a further advantage, as we have already mentioned, by not requiring the services of any person to look after it.

In regard to the safety of gasoline in comparison with steam, might say it is almost an impossibility to explode our gasoline engine. There is no fire in any way in connection with the engine, only a small electric spark on the inside which ignites the mixture of the gasoline. The engine is so arranged that only a certain amount of gasoline vapor can be exploded at any time, so there is no possibility of an explosion of the gasoline. In fact, at any time while the engine is running, there is not more than half a cup full of gasoline anywhere in the engine, unless the
gasoline storage tank is in the base of the engine, where we place them sometimes, or we have them where the tank is placed outside the engine altogether.

We trust we have covered all the points that you required especial attention to in your letter, but we will be very pleased to hear from you if there is any further information we can give you. We would be pleased to receive your order, and are in a position to fill same very promptly.

Thanking you in anticipation of an early reply, we remain,

Respectfully yours,

Memo for Deputy re small-pox at Sault Ste. Marie.

I find in the communication of G. L. King of the Shingwauk Home, dated 13th inst., a complaint that the small-pox hospital of the town of Sault Ste. Marie is a menace to the staff and pupils of the school.

Regarding the complaint I would say that, if the staff and pupils have been vaccinated properly, they cannot take small-pox, even though exposed. Further, that the mere passing of the building, in which cases of small-pox are confined, does not create a practical danger to passers-by. The law in Ontario provides that contagious disease hospitals cannot be established nearer than one hundred and fifty yards to an occupied dwelling. If Mr. King finds that this building is nearer than one hundred and fifty yards to the Home, of course an injunction might be obtained, but as the effect of the hospital upon the value of the property is not a matter of concern to this Dep't I cannot advise action along the line suggested in Mr. King's letter.

HIS LORDSHIP, THE HON. MR. JUSTICE HAGEE:

MAY IT PLEASE YOUR LORDSHIP:

We the Grand Jurors at the present Court of Assize beg leave to present as follows:

We welcome your Lordship on this your first visit to this prosperous town - the metropolis of New Ontario,- and trust your life will long be spared to adorn the Bench.

We have examined the jail, and found seventeen prisoners in custody, three of whom are there on account of their age and poverty. We think a home should be provided for the aged and infirm other than the common jail.

We are pleased to report that several improvements have been made in the jail during the past year, but we would recommend that sanitary improvements be made in the female ward, and that proper lockers be provided for prisoners clothing. We found the jail neat and clean, and the prisoners properly cared for.

Though we had to investigate three serious charges, we think this large District is as free from crime as could be reasonably expected.

We have examined the General Hospital and find forty-five patients therein, and we think the managers of this institution should be highly commended on account of the neatness and cleanliness of the building, and the kind attention shown to the patients.

We also examined the Shingwauk Home, and found fifty-seven Indian children therein, all of whom are being taught the English language, and trained in habits of industry so that they may become good citizens.

We cannot close this presentment without expressing the opinion that it should be made a criminal offence for any corporation or private individual to employ incompetent persons to run
engines, or hold other responsible positions, where the lives of other individuals are endangered.

ALL OF WHICH IS RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTED.

WATER SUPPLY IS NOT PURE

Report by Dr. Amyot Upon Ten Samples of Water Sent to him

Dr. J. H. Gisby recently sent ten samples of the water Steetton uses to Dr. Boyce, the provincial medical health officer at Toronto for analysis. Typhoid is very prevalent in the province and Dr. Gisby, who is the medical health officer there, determined to discover to what extent the water supply was responsible.

Steetton is supplied by eight springs; the Sault's water main along Catawba street, while the town water is acquired from the steel plant system which has a separate intake from the Sault. The town water was tested from the tap at Mr. McLean's drug store at Tagona; from the tap at Kelly's grocery on Catawba street from which water for the Sault's own system is drawn, and from eight springs, one of which is cemented and carefully covered. All the samples were drawn in special bottles furnished by Dr. Boyce which were carefully filled and sealed by Dr. Gisby. The report of the bacteriologist of the department was rather surprising. Out of the ten samples, three were found to be free from colon bacilli (the germ of typhoid). These two were the water taken from Dr. McLean's Tagona drug store, the town water derived from the cemented spring. The town water taken from Mr. Kelly's tap was not free of the bacilli.

"What significance attaches to the report?" the doctor was asked.

"Well, it shows why typhoid is so prevalent in Steetton. Typhoid is a water borne disease, and Steetton water just now is not being boiled. Of course the presence of colon bacilli in a given sample of water does not mean that the water is unfit to use all the time. It may happen that at that particular time there was an impurity present. It is quite possible that the water was not so semiclear. I believe the Sault water is in good condition in spite of the bad sample taken from Mr. Kelly's tap. When doubt exists, the water should be boiled."

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter No. 152067, I beg to say that I am reasonable at a loss how to make my defense. But first, that by simply stating a few facts, the Department will understand the case.

Miss Wesley wrote saying that she wished to visit her three children who came when some others came from Chapleau. We gave her a welcome, the freedom of the house and one of the best rooms for her own use while staying with us. She remained three weeks and went away seemingly satisfied.

But before she went she made a request that she be allowed to take Emily, a girl of 13 back with her. To this I was unable to assent in account of her treatment to a little girl whom she brought with her to attorn to a baby 10 months old, and also from the fact that she was not at her home in Chapleau, but living at Michipicoten siding, in a house where her husband, a son and some others were living and Emily would be able to work. I refused for these reasons.

As to the complaint that the children were neglected, it is utterly unfounded. But there is usually something to start a story on, so I will explain as I have received it from those who had the care of Emily.

She is one of those children who have acquired a certain habit—and which at her age is hard to break off. It was the season when the black fly was bad and Emily would persist in weaving her fingers in her hair. She was told that her hairdo would be left down, but still she could not stop. Mr. Fuller shows up the character of the girl, and by inference the untrustworthy character of her statements. The fact that he does not deny these statements is at once in keeping with the character of the man, and an evidence of his conscious integrity. no denial would be necessary. His letter therefore is not a defense but an explanation. That it is somewhat disconnected is quite typical of the man. That is his style especially when excited.

we could not entertain the idea for a moment.

I wish to state a few facts not to injure the girl Mary. I would have no objection to this, but to explain to the department the situation as we have had to deal with it. Four years ago we had Mr. Thomas the husband of our present junior teacher and a young man a friend of his working petitioning on a new roof on the main building of the Home. And while speaking of Mary's conduct Mr. Thomas told me that Mary had watched her chance and handed a note to this young man who was helping with the work. I did not see the note but I believe Mr. Thomas did. But it was to say that she, Mary, would go out to be with the man that night. I talked to the man and he confessed that it was true. That Mary did go and watch for him. Then when I talked to Mary she said that she had done this and that she had been with one of the older boys in the school also that she did wrong with an Indian boy who she said after was the father of the baby that was born. I am sure you will understand the care and anxiety all this gave us. And had the baby been alive we
would have followed the Father. I learned since that he is dead. We decided to do something in connection with the school for while it seemed hard to send the girl away we could not keep Mary with the other girls. So we began to look about for a good home for her. Dear Mr. Scott,

In accordance with your request I wish to submit the following report on the Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie Ont.

FARMING CONDITIONS.

Tile drainage is badly needed on about 35 acres; most of this land is good soil but very little is produced from it because of the wet condition. To get any kind of results this land should be tiledrained. The cost of this would be approximately $400.00.

BARN & OUTBUILDINGS.

The outbuildings, barns, stables, etc. are much below the standard found on the ordinary farm.

They are very badly arranged which makes the chores very difficult. The cattle barn, where the feed and bedding is kept, is 500 ft. from the horse barns and sheep stable; the feed and bedding consequently have to be carried this distance by hand. The stock have to be watered at the back door of the school.

There is no hog pen, the hogs are kept in corners of the barn, in empty stalls and in the chicken house. There is no decent place to keep sheep, only an old low shed without any windows. The main barn is a structure 30' X 50' with a basement under only part of it. This basement is too low and has only about one quarter enough window space to give the animals the proper amount of light (a cow requires 5 to 7 sq. ft. of window space and 600 cu. ft. air space). This basement is much too small, the cattle are literally packed in the barn.

There is no implement shed, the implements stand outside buried in snow. The chicken house is old and does not embody any of the modern ideas of a poultry house.

The buildings should be moved closer together, the barn should be raised 1½ ft. and the basement continued the full length of the barn, the cattle should be stood in two rows lengthwise. Up-to-date staunchins, a concrete floor, a litter carrier and more windows should also be put in.

A new implement shed, hog pen, chicken house, and a sheep barn are badly needed.

SCHOOL.

The schoolroom is very badly lighted, having windows at both sides. It is extremely difficult to see the work on the blackboard, frosted glass should be put in in the north side windows.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6211, file 469-1, part 3)
The children are in attendance from 9 A.M. until 4 P.M.; when they are needed for work they are taken out of school and consequently miss a great many lessons. A system of vocational education should be introduced for the senior grades. One half day in school and one half day for work. It is important that each child, not only receives a complete course of study in the school, but that they get proper instructions along farming and industrial lines as well.

For the girls I think a course of sewing should be put on. At the Mohawk and Muncey Institutes a sewing instructor teaches the girls to make almost all of the clothes worn by the pupils in attendance. This is a splendid training and will be of great value to them in after life. The only training that they get at the present time is mending.

IN GENERAL.—
The environment of the Shingwauk Home is not conducive of the best results under present conditions. An industrial school which has conditions poorer than are found at many Indian homes must fail in its purpose of preparing the pupils for the work they will have to do in after life.

The buildings at the Shingwauk Home will be to a certain extent the ideal of the pupil. An industrial school should embody up-to-date farm buildings, equipment and management to which the graduates could look back as being the ideal which they must sometime attain.

In conclusion I must congratulate the Rev. Mr. Fuller, principal, on being able to obtain the splendid results in the past under such adverse conditions. I feel that the years of faithful service he has given at the Shingwauk Home should be recognized and rewarded, and that from some source the necessary funds might be obtained to give him the proper equipment for the educations of the pupils at his school.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

I beg to say that I have just been notified by the Rev. B. P. Fuller Principal of the Shingwauk Home, that he has sent his resignation to the Arch Bishop.

Mr. Fuller informs me that he is resigning as Principal on account of interference on the part of Miss Bettrell in his duties.

Miss Bettrell was sent to the home here by the Women's Auxiliary of the Church of England from Ottawa, she has undermined his authority and have turned the Children and other inmates of the home against him, and by his conversation I am led to believe that the Arch Bishop takes her part.

It will be a great calamity if Mr. Fuller is allowed to leave this Institution. He is a very capable man, a hard worker, doing every kind of work to advance the home and the Indian Children under his care. He works on the Farm just the same as the Farmer hard for that purpose. I have known him to do Farm work all week and preach three times on Sunday.

I am informed by those who knew that for some time before Mr. Fuller took charge of the Shingwauk, that the church authorities were seriously thinking of closing up the place; it was so heavy in debt, they induced Mr. Fuller to take charge and he went at the work with all his might and in a short time had it running very smoothly and has the place nearly clear of debt, and is getting where he could devote more of his time to the inside management of the home. I venture to say that if Mr. Fuller leaves the Home now that in less than three years it will be back to the same position it was in when he took charge.

Miss Bettrell has on several occasions I am told sent letters to the Arch Bishop complaining of Mr. Fuller and it seems that...
Arch Bishop believed her and censured Mr Fuller for her untruths.

As far as the Indian Children are concerned it will be a very great misfortune to them the day that Mr Fuller leaves the Home.

His whole heart is in his work for the Indians and Indian children.

He was beloved by them all until this woman got in her undermining work. I personally have had a great friend in Mr Fuller and he has often driven down to the Garden River Reserve to assist me and he has been of great assistance to me in many ways towards the betterment of the Indians.

Seeing that the Department of Indian Affairs is paying so much towards this institution I am in hopes that you can do something to get Mr Fuller to remain, and I hope I am not asking too much when I ask you to bring some pressure to bear on the Arch Bishop whereby Mr Fuller will have a free hand in engaging what help he requires without interference from the English Church at Ottawa or elsewhere, or even from the Arch Bishop himself.

Mr. Scott,

I beg to submit the following report on the Shingwauk

Farm Conditions.

A large part of the farm is low and wet. This land is rendered almost useless on this account. The City Council are constructing a large outlet drain for the purpose of draining the Golf course. This drain will provide a splendid outlet for this low land and I would strongly recommend that a system of tile drainage be provided. Eighty per cent of the best farms of Ontario are provided with tile drainage. I would estimate the cost of the tile at between $500 and $600. The increase in yield from this would pay 100% on the investment, as it will make the difference between a good crop and a poor crop and in some years no crop at all.

Barns and Outbuildings.

Improvements.

(1) A new sheep pen and drive shed combined has been erected since my last visit.
(2) A new chicken house.
(3) A new hog pen.

The above buildings fill a long felt need.

The barn is a structure 30' X 50', with a basement under only part of it. This basement is very low and extends under only part of the barn. It has only one-quarter enough window space, and no proper arrangements for feeding. Each cow requires about six square feet window space and 600 cubic feet air space to give best results. The stock kept in this basement are too crowded and could not be expected to give even average results. Feeding arrangements are very poor and out of date. Many Indian farmers have far better cattle barns than this one.
The buildings are too far apart to make the choring easy, and a great deal more time and labour is taken up because of this.

I would recommend that a new basement barn 36' X 60' be built along modern lines closer to the school than the old building. The old barn could be utilized for other purposes, such as storing feed, implements, and etc.

There is no silo for storing feed in. I consider that in successful farming in this locality a silo is absolutely necessary for success. The supply of succulent food throughout the winter months makes up for the absence of green pasture and the flow of milk is in this way kept up. Silage is a much cheaper food than grain or hay and is much more palatable.

I would recommend that a silo be built.

(1) The school room is lighted on both sides and consequently the children often cannot see the work on the boards. The blackboard space is small and cut up badly. The windows on the north side should be closed up and more windows opened up on the southside. A blackboard could be put on the north side.

(2) There is no root cellar and the perishable fruit and vegetables are stored in the boys' living room. This is not fair to the pupils or a good place to keep the potatoes, etc., as at times there is too much heat and they spoil, consequently. A root cellar should be built with a door opening to the kitchen.

(3) The girls and boys dormitories are on the second floor. There are no lavatories closer than the main floor. This makes it very difficult in case of sickness, etc. A lavatory should be provided on the same flat as the dormitories for both the boys and girls.

In General.

The environment of the Shingwauk Home is such that the children placed there for training do not graduate with the correct ideas in respect to care of stock, arrangement of buildings, kind of buildings, etc.
If this school is to fulfil the purpose for which it is intended, the environment must be such that the pupils will graduate with correct ideas on methods of farming, feeds, feeding, buildings, breeds of stock, arrangements of buildings, land drainage, etc.

Some of our Indian farmers are very much in advance (so far as up-to-date equipment is concerned) of this school.

I submit that this is a condition that should be rectified in the near future.

In conclusion I can do nothing but congratulate the Reverend Mr. Fuller on the splendid showing he is making under such adverse conditions. He should be given a free hand to carry on the work of the farm and I sincerely hope that the necessary improvements are made in order that he may make a greater success from the standpoint of preparing the pupils for the work they will have to do in after life.

(R.H. Abraham),
Agricultural Representative.

Dear Mr Scott:

During the several years which have elapsed since this Society took over, from the dioceses concerned, the administration of the Anglican Indian Residential Schools, we have experienced serious and chronic difficulties with the Rev. B.P. Fuller.

These difficulties concerned, largely, the persistent refusal of Mr Fuller to co-operate with our Commission, and to observe such every-day business principles as the notification of supplies ordered, and the forwarding for payment of accounts received.

We have decided that the interests of the work cannot be further endangered through a continuance of apparently fruitless efforts to secure reasonable co-operation on the part of Mr Fuller; and have, in consequence, notified him that his engagement as Principal of the Shingwauk Home will terminate on the last day of September of this year.

I beg to acknowledge your favour of the 2nd instant enclosing copy of letter received by your Department from the Deputy of Indian Affairs relative to the transfer of the above property to that Department and instructions to investigate the title and prepare conveyance, etc.

I have made a search of the title and find that in February 1875 the property was conveyed by the Reverend Edward F. Wilson to the Right Reverend P. D. Faquier, Bishop of the Diocese of Algoma "in trust for the use of the Indian Industrial Institution called and known as the Shingwauk Home". Subsequently in January 1910 by quit claim deed the Reverend Edward F. Wilson quit claims in the usual form to the Incorporated Synod of the Diocese of Algoma. This deed was registered at Victoria, chapter 60, incorporating the Bishop of the Diocese of Algoma, and also recites "6 Edward 7th, Chapter 141, Incorporating the Synod of the Diocese of Algoma. It also recites that some doubt has arisen as to the power of the Synod to mortgage or sell the lands comprising the Shingwauk Home, and the Reverend Edward Wilson gave the quit claim deed in full compliance to the compensation of the land to the Synod in fee simple and conveying same from all restrictions, trusts and conditions in the deed made by him to Bishop Faquier in 1875. The result of these conveyances is to vest the property comprising the Shingwauk Home in the Incorporated Synod of the Diocese of Algoma without same being subject to any trust.

In the letter from the Department of Indian Affairs to your Department, dated April 23rd, 1930, some suggestions are made in regard to the conditions to be inserted in the conveyance from the Diocese to the Department. I would like to be certain that these conditions are all that should be imposed. You will note a proposal which should the Department come into use the party in accordance with the terms imposed, then the land shall at that time be purchased by the Department at a current valuation to be agreed upon by the executive committee of the Diocese of Algoma and the Department.

MR. PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF THE KIWANIS CLUB:

Your Committee investigating the conditions of the Shingwauk Home Indian School, visited the Home Friday, May 8th, 1931, and wish to report to you as follows:

Rev. C. F. Hives, Supt., met us and we were shown every consideration and courtesy, and we wish to submit that a letter of thanks be forwarded immediately by the Secretary to Mr. Hives, extending our appreciation.

THE SHINGWAUK Home was built about sixty years ago. It is of stone outer wall construction, the interior being entirely of wood and plaster construction. The building is in very bad need of repairs throughout.

Due to the heating plant consisting of three boilers being inadequate to heat the building, it is necessary, and they are using stoves in all class rooms and play rooms. Electric heaters are being used in staff quarters instead of stove. This condition we consider a most dangerous fire hazard, which should not exist in any public building. There are ninety-nine pupils in the building - sixty girls and thirty-nine boys.

The fire fighting equipment in the building is entirely inadequate and would be useless in case of fire, due to the locations in the building. The fire escapes from the boys' dormitories consists of one straight ladder outside of the window. This window must be raised and can only be lifted to give a thirty inch opening, to let the boys out on the platform from which they must go down a straight ladder one at a time. The landing platform has no guard rail on opposite end to ladder, which is a most dangerous condition, and if crowded with boys leaving this building, no doubt would be the cause of serious accidents.

We regret to advise that even a worse condition exists in the fire escape arrangement from the girls' dormitory. The exit is also through a window the same as the boys. The straight ladder lands on the peak of a pitch roof of a frame building. After landing on this roof the ladder must be thrown down the eave where another straight ladder is provided to reach the ground. A more deplorable condition exists at this point. The ladder is approximately eighteen inches below the eave of the roof, which necessitates the pupils hanging over the eave to reach the ladder. There are no guards above the eave and it would take extra care on the part of any man to reach this ladder, let alone these young girls such as there are found in this institution.

We cannot comment too strongly on the fact that the interior of this building is nothing less than a dangerous fire trap. The existence throughout the building of so many stoves greatly increases the possibilities of fire.

We also find that the roof of this building is in bad need of repair. There are many leaks in the dormitories as well as other parts of the building. It is necessary, on rainy days, to place pails and tubs in many places throughout the building to catch the water coming through the roof. These leaks have left the ceiling in a very bad condition, the plaster being off in many places throughout the boys' and girls' dormitories, sewing room and reading rooms.

All
All the class rooms are overcrowded. The junior class room with crowded accommodations for forty pupils. This class room is in very poor state of repairs. There are no toilet accommodations for this room and it is necessary for these children to go down stairs.

The girls' dormitory is like the rest of the building, of entirely wooden floors, and wooden partitions. There is only one toilet and one bath in connection with this dormitory. The junior girls' dormitory is practically in the same condition as the senior. These girls use the same toilet and bath as the senior girls which means there is only one toilet and one bath for all girls in connection with their dormitories.

Both the boys' and girls' play rooms are in very bad shape. In the girls' play room there is only one bench which, when crowded, will only accommodate eleven children. There are only three toilets in operation in connection with this play room.

The laundry department is entirely inadequate for the number of pupils attending this school.

We cannot bring to your attention too strongly the fact that all stairways throughout this building are wooden construction and the lack of suitable fire escapes makes this building a most dangerous fire trap, entirely unsuitable for a school. We are advised that this building was condemned by the Fire Chief a year or two ago and that this report is on file at the Department at Ottawa.

We also bring to your attention that, in view of the most unsatisfactory sanitary conditions, and fire hazard existing in the use of this building as a home and school, and after seeing the deplorable conditions that do exist brought to their attention, the late Government provided funds in the estimates of 1930 for the erection of a new Indian School here to replace the present Shingwauk Home.

The Grand Jury, at the last sitting of the Supreme Court here, visited the Shingwauk Home and recommended the immediate construction of a new Indian School.

We further wish to suggest to you that the construction of this new Indian Home could be done now cheaper than at any later date.

In view of the deplorable conditions of the Shingwauk Home, as shown above, we recommend that this Club pass a resolution, bringing to the attention of the Government, the unsatisfactory conditions existing in the Shingwauk Home here, and strongly urging them to proceed immediately with the construction of a new Indian school here, before the inevitable happens, and this building is burned with a heavy loss of human life, and that this resolution be forwarded to The Hon. Minister of Interior, and a copy of same forwarded to The Right Hon. Prime Minister and Mr. T. E. Simpson, M. P.

Respectfully submitted;

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT

Pursuant to instructions in your letter of the 4th instant, I have to report that, when in Sault Ste. Marie early this month, I made a very careful inspection of the Shingwauk Home. While the particular criticisms in the resolution of the local Kiwanis Club were founded in fact, the general conditions at this school are not quite so serious as those who are pressing for a new building would have us believe.

The interior of the building is so constructed, that there is no doubt a serious fire hazard. This hazard is increased by the supplementary heating units - 7 stoves in classrooms, playrooms, laundry, Principal's office and Principal's residence and one-half dozen electric heaters in the staff bedrooms.

To put this old building, part of which was erected 57 years ago, in a safe condition, would be so expensive that it is out of the question. If school is to be conducted until a new building is provided, steps must be taken to minimize the risk of loss of life in the event of fire. Some months ago we authorized the engagement of a night watchman, who would constantly patrol the building. I find that the Rev. C. Hives, the Principal, has relied a little too much on this employee. He has not sufficiently emphasized the fire drill and the fire escapes themselves.

We have been allowing $50 per month for the night watchman and the school has been giving him his board. I asked Mr. Hives if he was one hundred per cent satisfied that the man was on the job every minute of the night. He hesitated before replying that he was "reasonably sure". I asked him if we made the remuneration $75 a month if he could get a man on whom we could absolutely rely. He replied he could not, as from the 15th instant, there has been on duty a night watchman who is thoroughly reliable.

With reference to the fire escapes themselves, I arranged for a guardrail on the boys' fire escape and instructed that a fire axe was to be always handy to the window opening thereof. The escape from the girls' dormitory was in good condition, as reported by the Kiwanis Club Committee, and, on the 9th instant, I
arranged for two carpenters to come out to the school and gave them instructions concerning a window outside the window and a platform to the fire escape—all properly surrounded by guardrails. Further, the ladder fire escape was raised 5 ft., to be easily reached, and was properly protected. The Kiwanis Committee reports concerning a straight ladder which lands on the peak of a pitch roof; but this is not a fire escape, as it leads only to the roof of the building.

To lessen the general risk, I instructed the carpenters to punch a door through an interior wall which divides the building on the dormitory floor. In the event of fire at one end of the building, the boys or the girls, as the case may be, could be moved to the other side to descend the fire escape or the interior staircase there.

The roof of the building is in rather poor condition and I authorized the carpenters to re-shingle those patches where there was any leaking.

The building accommodates 95 or 100 pupils without any real crowding, and I instructed the Principal to see that the number did not run over the 100 at any time. The boys' dormitory has plenty of air space and the girls' is not seriously crowded. In the past, the classrooms have been overcrowded, but I have instructed the Principal to try the half-day system, which will remedy this situation forthwith. The toilet and bath facilities are inadequate, but remedial measures need not be considered as the Department intends to discontinue the use of this building in the early future. The playrooms and the dining room have not been used for several years and I gave the Principal instructions in this connection. The matron at the school, Miss Botterell, is now practically wholly blind, and I intend to write to Dr. Westgate with a view to having her retired.

It should be remembered that this building is not a high structure and that there are no pupils more than 2½ stories from the ground. The dormitories are not locked at night and the windows to the fire escapes open easily. With your permission, I wish to instruct Mr. Indian Agent Sims to regularly inspect this school and to give particular attention to the safety of the children.

With your concurrence, I wish to authorize a few minor improvements, as follows:

1. Electric lights over the fire escapes.
2. Sheet iron and asbestos protection around the smoke pipes from stoves in kitchen and both playrooms.

3. Calcimine and -
3. Calcimine and brushes for decorating the dormitories and a little paint to complete the henhouse.

4. Half screens for certain windows.

5. $150 for repairs to the farmer's cottage. The farm instructor, who is a good officer, has recently been married, and Mr. Hives wishes to give him one of the old stone houses to himself.

6. One horse to complete a second team for the school.

I may say that I was quite critical concerning the lack of cleanliness of certain parts of the old building and on the school grounds. Mr. Hives assures me that conditions are now much better than when he took it over, but he is going to take full advantage of what may be done to have each child and each child's responsibilities daily for jobs that they can do. Mr. Hives now knows the Department's wishes and is not going to treat them lightly, as I told him that we would close the school if the church authorities and himself felt that the difficulties and dangers were too great.

There are five buildings that should remain after the new main building is erected - the chapel, the farmer's residence, two summer cottages on the river and the new henhouse. The old hospital across the main road and all the other buildings, including the barn, should eventually be removed.

Dear Sir:

The matter of the retirement of our Headmatron is being taken into consideration today by our Commission in Winnipeg. While Mr Ferrier, the Superintendent of Indian Education was here last June, we discussed this matter, and it was deemed advisable that her retirement should be effected. But after looking more thoroughly into the matter, I came to the conclusion that we would not gain very much by doing so. I found that one at least of the other members of the staff would go with her. This particular agent, who is our Senior teacher, is a valuable member of our staff. I cannot speak too highly of her work both in the classroom and out. We have had, and are having some very encouraging results, and at the present time we have ten pupils attending High School. I know from experience that it is not easy to get a teacher into our work, who is capable of getting the desired results that we have been able to achieve. I am therefore most anxious that she should remain. I may say the reason that our Senior teacher would leave is because she feels that Miss Botterel would require her. The main reason for Miss Botterel's retirement is on account of her affliction of Blindness, which, I may say she has sustained in the work here, and, according to medical authority, on account of the nervous strain to which she has been subjected in the work. Some twenty years ago, Miss Botterel gave up a good position in an office to take up work here in Shingwauk Home. In those days the work must have been extremely hard on account of the very small staff the school was allowed. Her blindness is a handicap, but since Mr Ferrier's visit here, on my recommendation, the Commission have given us another agent who has taken over a great deal of the work heretofore done by the head matron. Miss Botterel relieved of that work acts in the capacity of an advisory agent, and looks after the correspondence with the W.A. branches. I may say that this part of the work is very important, and as Miss Botterel is well acquainted with that part of the work, it is very well looked after.
I may say that Miss Botterel is well liked by the children, and according to our records, we have very few changes in the personnel of the staff.

Another consideration which must be met, is Miss Botterel's future. Miss Botterel is 48 yrs of age. She has given nearly twenty years of her life to this work, but she is not an old woman. In fact she is very healthy excepting for her unfortunate affliction of blindness. One has to look at the matter from its humane side as well as the business and practical side, and it does not seem altogether right to lay aside a strong healthy woman in her prime of life. If she leaves the work here, with the very slender means she will have at her disposal, her life will be a very dull and hopeless one.

My feeling in the matter is that she should be allowed to stay on as she is until the new building is accomplished. She knows this building. She can get around it just as well as I can, and taking everything into consideration, I would sincerely recommend that the Department withdraw their decision, and allow the Commission to retain her services until the new school is built.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I hope you will pardon the liberty I take in writing you, but the matter of which I write is a vital one.

As Miss Botterell's friend, Mr. Hives has told me that you have felt it advisable to have her removed from her position here, with no reason given, but naturally it is to be inferred on account of her sight. If it is on account of Miss Botterell's sight, we cannot understand why she was not dismissed sooner. For eight years in exactly the same state she has carried on her work faithfully and successfully, often entirely on her own, while day after day Mr. Fuller was off in his car making a slave of himself for the public and his many friends who imposed too much on good nature.

When I first came here in 1921 Miss Botterell worked better with Mr. Fuller than anyone else as she understood his violent unreasonable passions. After hearing last year that Miss Botterell was to be discharged, I could not but make a deduction knowing that Mr. Fuller had made a vow that he would get Miss Fuller, Miss Botterell, and myself out of here before he was through and I very much fear that he has impressed you falsely as he has done so many of the people about the Sault concerning Miss Botterell.

Poor Mr. Fuller is a self deluded warped man with the most unreasonable jealous unfair mind, and cunning enough to appear one thing and deliberately act another, and yet a man of some very excellent qualities, though he would stand for nothing that did not fit in with his will. He trusted the place implicitly to Miss Botterell's judgment and management when it suited him. He said he never took a holiday. Sometimes it was one long holiday. Didn't want to say he did nothing so he did frivolously at times, in early spring, in spasmodic fits, in the management that all right on a dead level line.

As I have said before, Miss Botterell could work with him as no others could. Then came the horrible question of correspondence when those who could get no answer from him wrote Miss Botterell. She always showed him the letters and when he
told her to leave them to him, she did, but half were never answered. When the order came that matrons must answer all letters, she again got into disfavour. He told me she had the nice part while he had all the cheering and lugging. Then when the Commission asked Miss Fuller to assist her father, she too got into trouble. Mr. Fuller just confiscated the letters.

When in desperation Dr. Westgate asked Miss Botterell to take full charge of requisitioning and supplies, and it was "Bedlam" let loose. How she continued to live in her usual manner was a marvel to us all, but she said she had become accustomed to him.

When she had the requisitions complete and handed over to Mr. Fuller for signature, etc., they lay on his desk for days. The Commission sent a young man to assist Mr. Fuller. This he refused to allow him to do and again serious trouble arose. Mr. Fuller was furious with Miss Botterell for not keeping the young man out of the staff dining-room other than meal times. Then Mr. Fuller refused to have anything more to do with any of us and had his meals carried over to him by his sister. He repulsed every effort of Miss Botterell's, Miss Fuller's, and Mr. Dill's to come to some peaceful conclusion. The young man of course corresponded with the Commission but we knew nothing more till we heard that Mr. Fuller was to be given a Mission.

Then Mr. Fuller appealed to the Primate. He asked us if we were willing that he should stay under altered conditions. We were indeed sorry for him as, in spite of all, we had a regard for Mr. Fuller and from Miss Botterell to the last member of the staff, we said decidedly yes, but it seemed that for years and years the Commission had been coaxing, threatening, and begging him to comply with some system. Dr. Westgate can testify to the fact that never by letter, word or deed did Miss Botterell make any complaint. Of course Mr. Fuller was angry because Miss Fuller would not go with him. He had to keep his sister and she could not afford to give up her position as neither he nor she had a cent. Again he blamed us. All his life her welfare was not at heart, but just his own personal feelings at that time, though I believe now he sees the wisdom of her staying here. Since last summer a reconciliation was made between Miss Fuller and her father brought about largely by Miss Botterell coaxing her to put her pride away and not wait to be asked to visit him.

At Miss Botterell's instigation, we started a subscription for Mr. Fuller. When I had collected three hundred dollars, I met with so many hints that we were putting him out that in disgust I passed it over to two other ladies. What possible influence could a mere staff or matron have, had he been able to fulfill his business obligations and satisfy the Commission? Dr. Westgate knoweth this.

You wonder what my object is. Well, Mr. Ferrier, it is this. I appeal to you as a gentleman and Christian to give Miss Botterell
time to adjust herself. Her life, her heart, her all has been here with her work which instinctively she knows like the alphabet. I tell you, the girls of this school would have had a different record if it had not been for her untiring watchfulness. Girls that refused to work or to try the entrance for me for fear they would have to go among the whites, she handled with her unusual ability. Mary Simons, now nursing in an Indian hospital, is one example. Would you not consider, Mr. Ferrier, allowing Miss Botterell to continue here. I promise you if needed, I am here and ready to help make up for any deficiencies her sight may cause.

At least could she stay till she sees Agnes through? She is as dear to Agnes as a real mother, and Agnes has her A.T.C.M., at Miss Botterell's expense. She will be ready for Normal the year after this. Agnes says you have promised to help her when the time comes. My plan is to try and get back on the Public School staff at Stratford. Then I could take Miss Botterell with me. Agnes could come to Stratford Normal if I get my position there back again. With anything you can do for her, I will try to make up the rest. She would then be in a position to help Miss Botterell who has in times past spent her small salary foolishly on things that Mr. Fuller just refused to get for the workers.

Again I must apologize for this letter as I know you are a busy man. It could be endorsed by Canon and Mrs. Colliton, workers who one after another could not stand the upsetting life, the Hayes' family who lived here, and on ad infinitum. I do not write maliciously, but that you might get a true inner view and can judge accordingly. I feel sure if you really knew the truth, you would sympathize with Miss Botterell, whose last vestige of sight went after one of Mr. Fuller's terrible rows. Miss Fuller will tell you that. I am writing in confidence for her sake, as she still loves her father for his many good qualities, but she never knew when she could be sure of peace—until Mr. Hayes came here. I hope that you will pardon this letter which I hate, but which is of such vital importance to most of us here, that I have ventured it. Again I say that if you could see your way clear to change your judgements, you would never regret it.

The Commission, the W.A.S., and Mr. Hayes are all satisfied that it is for the good of the school to have Miss Botterell here. Since your visit here last summer the system has been changed as you advised and more time is put on the girls' household training. As Mr. Hayes has advised, only the very promising will get extra attention in the classroom which I generally give outside of school hours.

Hoping that you may see this in the light I have tried to write it,

Very respectfully yours,

Alice Davies
Senior Teacher, Shingwauk.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada
