Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 31st ultimo, #15-0-1, and my reply to the same on the 7th inst., re the retirement of Miss Botterel from the Head Matronship of the Shingwauk Home, I beg to state that this important matter has received the most careful attention of our Commission, and in view of the following communications received from the school management, I have been instructed to request your Department to kindly agree to permit Miss Botterel to continue in her present office, at any rate, until the new main school building has been provided:

(1) The Rev. Principal Hives telegraphed to our Commission on April 11th, stating that he very much regretted the action of your Department with regard to Miss Botterel, and added that he did not consider the showing of the school with regard to the health of pupils, the general progress made, and the results obtained under her Head Matronship warranted such action.

(2) On April 16th, a letter was received from one of the leading staff agents, who refers to Miss Botterel as follows:

"Her work, her heart, her life, her brain, her all are being given for this school. She knows it as she knows the letters of the alphabet .......... Miss Botterel has faithfully, watchfully, loyally served in this work for eighteen years, giving up a good position as stenographer in the Department of Agriculture in Ottawa for the love and urge of missionary work. She has always smoothed over troubles whenever they arose. It is true she has
been deprived of her eyesight, but with her own trained girls, in addition to the Head Matron's work she has done endless substituting, even in the kitchen at times, and never was the work so well done. She directed the girls in this work, and an excellent training it was ..........

Had it not been for Miss Botterel, the story of the girls at this school would have been a very different one. When Mary Simons, now a fully qualified Nurse, was in the Entrance class, and refused to take the examination because she would have to mingle with White girls, Miss Botterel dealt with her as she did with Louise Jackson and Barbara Michael, and it was not long until all the brighter girls looked forward to higher education ......... To take her work from her, the only work she can ever know now and which she just naturally does so well, would be cruel.

A healthy, vigorous person, living the rest of her life, with no sight, and nothing to do, would be slow torture. If you can use your influence with the Department to alter their decision in this matter, I will vouch for Miss Botterel, and make up for any drawback to the work which her lack of sight may mean, although no such drawback has as yet existed."

In the light of the above communications, our Commission feel justified in asking your Department not to press for Miss Botterel's retirement at the present time. Some years ago when Mr. Fuller was filling the position of Principal of this school, and he failed hopelessly in the matter of answering communications from the Commission, and in submitting the reports they required, Miss Botterel was asked to undertake these duties with the assistance of another member of the staff, and they were well and promptly done. Although she is deprived of the priceless gift of sight, her sane judgment, sympathetic understanding, neverfailing patience, and otherwise generally good and helpful influence, combine to make her one of the most efficient staff agents our Commission
have ever had in the Indian Residential School service, and the members sincerely trust that you may be able to accede to their earnest request, that she be allowed to continue in her present position.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I inspected the Garden River Agency at Sault St. Marie on the 11th and 13th instant and beg to submit the following report.

I visited the Shingwauk Home and found everything very satisfactory, insofar as the management is concerned. The buildings are old and dilapidated looking and nothing very much can be done to improve them. The grounds have been very much improved this last year. The interior has been cleaned and painted. The dormitories are spotlessly clean and tidy. The whole interior shows a vast improvement since last year and reflects great credit upon the Rev. Principal for his efforts. All the pupils remaining in residence looked happy and well cared for. Some of the bigger boys were out on the land ploughing and cultivating, others were working in the garden. The boys and girls are getting a good experience and training here, which will be valuable to them in later life.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will any grant be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. All Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils mentioned in the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. 8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

the sore need of repairs were matters discussed with you on the eighth instant and I need not comment on them further except to add that a sum of $2040.58 such as the accompanying estimates call for would suffice to place the Institution in a good state of repair for many years to come.

The present state of equipment is of the most wretched description. I am aware that to place the Homes on a par with the Government Schools in point of equipment will have to be done by degrees; but as a first step in this direction I would suggest, subject to your approval, that fifty of the wooden bedsteads which have been in use for over fifteen years be discarded and iron bedsteads similar to those used in the Northwest Schools be substituted. These bedsteads can be purchased for $9.50 each.

Another matter I would wish to lay before the Department for their favourable consideration is the necessity and importance of adopting some more satisfactory and economical method of heating the Institution. The consumption of fuel under the present system of using stoves is enormous and out of all proportion to our means, our expenditures on fuel last year amounting as it did to $792.59. The introduction of a more modern heating system would not only prove a great boon to the pupils in the Institution but it would be the means whereby a large saving might be made in our expenditure.

I have not submitted any estimate of cost of erecting...
a separate building for the accommodation of the girls because I understand from the Department that there will be no funds available this year for this purpose; but I trust that the Department will give this very necessary and most important matter their favourable consideration next year.

Having made a thorough inspection of the home as requested, I have concluded that the only proper method of heating the building is by a "Steam Plant" and this of a modern construction—to erect and establish a plant with sufficient radiating surface to heat it comfortably would cost about $1200.00—in making my estimate I have based my calculation for a good supply of surface—there are changes that could be made which would lessen the cost but for the present it would make it so little that it would scarcely be worth considering—a "Hot Air Plant" could be placed in the home at a less cost—I should not recommend it—the situation and peculiar conditions of the building would necessitate considerable attention to design a "Hot Air Plant"—which added to the cost of the plant would nearly amount to as much as for steam—with the possibility of the air becoming unwholesome and under certain conditions of the wind—it will be understood that in submitting the Estimate for the Steam—there will not include any Carpentry or mason work that may be necessary.

Yours Truly,

OTTAWA 5th June 1895

The Honorable
T. Mayne Daly,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs:

An application has been received from the Principal of the Shingwauk Home and Mr. Plummer of Sault Ste Marie, who represents the Department on the Committee of Management of that Institution, in which they ask for a Grant to assist in putting the Main Building in a proper state of repair; and in connection with this application the undersigned has the honor to report that in September last this Institution was inspected by an officer from the Department who reported that at the time of his visit he found the building referred to very much out of repair, it having been in constant use for more than 20 years, and with little, if anything, having been expended in keeping it in proper repair.

The Principal has submitted a detailed statement of the contemplated improvements, with an estimate of their probable cost, amounting to the sum of $2,490.58.
The attention of the Committee of Management was called to the dilapidated condition of the building and promises and since then some of the most necessary work has been done, but further improvement is still necessary to make the building suitable for the requirements of an Institution of its class.

Among the improvements proposed to be made is the introduction of a modern heating system, as up to the present the building has been warmed by stoves which is found to be inadequate and very expensive. The amount spent on fuel for last year was $800.

The pupils attending this school are drafted chiefly from the Indian Reserves in central Ontario, and the undersigned submits herewith a statement showing the Capital at the credit of the different Bands to which these pupils belong, also the number of pupils from each of the said Bands and the proportion of the total cost of the proposed repairs, namely $2,500 in round numbers, which it is proposed shall be borne by each of the Bands interested.

The undersigned would, therefore, respectfully recommend that the deduction as specified opposite the name of each Band in the statement above referred to be made from the Capital at the credit of the Band under the provisions of Section 70 of the Indian Act, and that authority be given...
to have the proposed repairs made in accordance with the plans and specifications submitted.

Provision is made by the Department for 100 pupils at $60 per capita per annum at this school and until the proposed improvements are made, that number cannot be accommodated.

Respectfully submitted,

Deputy Supt:Genl:
of Indian Affairs.

Memorandum,

To the Deputy Minister
of Indian Affairs

I have carefully examined the tenders received for Heating apparatus for the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste Marie.

That of Plummer and Young of Sault Ste Marie at $3,100 and of C. Beck of the same place at $2,950 should not be entertained, as the price in each case is too high and no details are given, especially as regards the quantity of surface radiation.

That of Keith & Fitzsimmons of Toronto at $1,700 should also be counted out as the size of the Boiler (No 7) is too small and less costly than No 8. The heating surface 2245 square feet is not sufficient. The Tender does not include building of Chimneys, converting of Lamp room into furnace room nor carpentering work necessary for the fitting of pipes &c. They estimate this work at $150 or $175; but it is believed that it would cost at least $300. That would bring the price up to at least $2,000 for a No 7 Boiler and radiators with 2245 square feet of surface, or about 90 cents per square foot.

That of Fiddes & Hogarth for the Gurney Foundry Company, at $2,280 does not include the building of Chimneys which would cost about $175, nor Brick foundation for Boiler say $20. These items would bring the Tender up to...
to $2,475 for a No 8 Twin Oxford Boiler with 41 Oxford radiators and all necessary apparatus and a radiation of 2744 square feet, equal to 90 cents per square foot.

That of the Bennett & Wright, Ltd at $2768 is for a No 8 Daisy Boiler and Safford Patent Radiators with a surface of 2900 square feet and all necessary pipes, fittings and work ready to fire up, equal to 96 cents per square foot.

That of W.H. Plummer & Co., at $2450 with $175 additional for Chimneys in all $2,625 does not specify the description of Boiler, but guarantees to put in a Hot Water Heating apparatus of approved make, which will give satisfaction; the Radiation being 2900 square feet, which is equal to 84 1/2 cents per square foot for the apparatus without chimneys or 90 cents including the chimneys. This Tender and that of Fiddes & Hogarth are about equal as to price and are lower than the others. As Plummer & Co. is a local firm well and favourably known to the Department, I would recommend that they be offered the contract on condition that they bind themselves to put in a No 8 Twin Daisy Furnace with at least 40 Radiators, having a radiation of 2900 square feet and all other necessary apparatus equal in every respect to that particularly specified in the Tender of Fiddes & Hogarth.

Plummer & Co., also quote prices for apparatus of a greater
greater heating capacity; but I am advised by Mr Cowan the Engineer of the Langevin Block who is in every way competent to give a reliable opinion in such matters that a surface radiation of 2900 square feet would be quite sufficient. He is also of opinion that the Daisy Boiler would be preferable (though the Oxford is also an excellent one) because in the event of one of the Sections being broken in the Daisy the broken part can be shut off from the other parts and the use of the Boiler continued, while in the Oxford the fire would have to be let out until repairs, which might take a long time, could be effected.

It might be stipulated in the Contract that Plummer & Co shall give to the Institution all carpentry and other work which can be done by the Artificers of such work, which could be arranged between the Contractors and the Principal, deducted from the amount of the Contract.

Respectfully submitted,

OTTAWA, 22nd March, 1899

The Acting Secretary:

About two years ago Judge Johnson and Mr King, Principal of the Shingwauk home had an interview with the Minister on the subject of putting up a building at the home for the accommodation of girls, nothing is on file to indicate what result, although no provision was made for such purpose.

Mr King now presents a petition of the Algoma Indian homes applying for a grant of $2700 to assist them in this object. The petition states that His Lordship, the Bishop of Algoma, has conditionally secured the sum of $2300, provided the building is completed and habitable by the 31st December 1899.

The Shingwauk home was started twenty-five years ago as a boys' school. In 1880 a home for girls called the Wawanosh, was put up about five miles from the Shingwauk and although it was under the same management an additional staff was required to look after the girl pupils. This arrangement, although very inconvenient, was carried on for about twelve years when the girls were transferred to the Shingwauk home on the score of economy.

When I visited this school about five years ago, I pointed out to His Lordship, the late Bishop Sullivan, how unsatisfactory the above arrangement was, and shortly after my leaving there, a new
Principal having been appointed, the girls were returned to their homes pending the erection of a school for their accommodation.

The Shingwauk Home under Mr King is giving good satisfaction and if the Department could see its way to assist in the erection of a building for girls in connection therewith, better results would yet be obtained as it would entail little, if any, expense in management and there is an unused per capita grant for 35 pupils.

It is well known that better results are obtained from educating a number of girls than in confining such efforts to boys alone, as when girls are educated and return to their Reserves and marry they exercise a beneficial influence upon their homes and surroundings, which is not so noticeable in the case of boys returning from school.

There are a large number of Indians who belong to the Church of England and who would be glad to avail themselves of an opportunity of sending their girls to this school.

The Shingwauk home building has lately been thoroughly over-hauled and repaired as well as equipped and there is plenty of school-room accommodation for the extra pupils desired. The situation is most charming and healthy and is now readily accessible.

Since our old school became exhausted at Shingwauk, some four years ago, we have found increasing difficulties to obtain the two to three hundred cords of wood needed each year for fire for our dilapidated buildings viz: Senior School, Laundry, Factory including steam engine, Farmers Cottage, Hospital, Chapel, and Cooking ranges.

The main building is heated with coal, the purchase of which is a heavy tax on our finances.

Last year, and the year before, we assisted to clear some land for a neighbour who permits us to take what wood he requires. This place has also become exhausted, and the only place now likely to obtain a similar privilege is on the Hauley location—three miles distant. The distance is a great drawback, and much time will be lost in taking the boys to and from, and my little work will be ruined if we bring them back at all.

Sir,

The question of obtaining wood for fuel for the homes is each year becoming a more difficult problem, and when it is a case of getting wood from home to get it.

I consider we are most fortunate in again obtaining the privilege of locating on the school's location, situated between two and three miles from Shingwauk; but in order to get out the required supply it will be necessary, like last year, to take winter boys divided into groups of six each, and work them alternate days, in the clopping etc., so to school a full day and work or half day.

This division of clay about, instead of half days system would be but a temporary arrangement & the supply only to these particular boys.

I trust the Department will sanction the arrangement made necessary by distance of the bush from home.

To the Board of Management,
Shingwauk Indian School.

Dear Sirs:

The Committee named by you and undersigned have made an examination of the school, particularly in regard to the prevalence of Tuberculosis and Typhoid Fever, and beg to report as follows:

1st. As to Tuberculosis.

It appears to us that the building occupied by the scholars lacks sufficient light, ventilation and recreation space. The ceilings are too low, but this would not be serious if they and the walls were bright in color and easily cleansed. The high wooden wainscoting and walls should be replaced by hard plaster, tile, or at least painted or calgonized in light color; the floors also are open and need renewing. What plaster there is is rough and thus favors the accumulation of dust in which tubercular bacilli thrive.

There is practically no recreation space provided and that used by the boys, we think positively injurious, as it is used as their wash and scrub room, is largely underground and lighted by only two half windows. The walls are dark and the whole apartment dingy.

The girls' recreation room has not the same faults, but as it is used also as a dining room, it is hardly a place in which they can romp and take necessary exercise.

The place allotted for sleeping room would probably be sufficient under ordinary conditions, but owing to the susceptibility of the inmates to tuberculosis, it is questionable if it would not be better to provide more space, or better still a means of changing the air in the rooms frequently.

We also find that there are a few children suffering from tuberculosis attending the school in whom the signs of disease are quite evident in the lungs, glands or bones. Such cases should never be admitted, and in cases where the disease develops in the school, should
be isolated and sent home or to some Sanitarium for the treatment of tuberculosis. This implies a more thorough examination of applicants for admission and if we may, we would suggest, that in addition to the examination now required, you inquire into the previous illnesses and family history of each applicant, and have the school physician make a thorough examination before such applicant is finally admitted. If cases with a marked pre-disposition to tuberculosis of incipient cases are not admitted, the health of the school will be safeguarded.

To sum up, we would advise the removal of all tuberculosis cases now present and as much as possible prevent the admission of other cases. Also a thorough renovation of the buildings; this to include disinfection by fumigation, also, as far as practicable, changes that would provide more recreation space, light and ventilation.

2nd. As to Typhoid Fever.

This disease has been very prevalent in the school, owing probably to its drainage contaminating its water supply. The sewerage and drainage from the building and outbuildings empties into a small bay or basin of the river in front of the school. A few yards lower down the river, the intake pipe is situated and thus in the current that drains the basin referred to. Besides this, there is the possibility of contamination of the water supply by the town sewerage entering the river at a higher level. The drains from the buildings are open.

We would suggest a thorough system of house drainage with closets, urinals and bath-rooms, a water supply independent of the river, say from a deep well pumped by a windmill or other power.

We find that as much as possible typhoid Fever is being prevented by boiling the water used by the inmates, but it is almost impossible to have instructions carried out by the scholars.

We have to thank Mr. King for the kindly way in which he facilitated our inspection of the premises, and we wish to add that the school is as
cleanly and as wholesome as its construction and inherent conditions will permit.

Signed,

S. R. Fleming, M.D.,
J. Douglas McLean, M.D.,
R. J. Gibson, M.D.

The Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

A condition of things admitting of no delay compels me to write you regarding the Indian Homes in this place: (the Shingwauk or Wawaunee).

The health of the pupils has for some time past been a cause for much anxiety to the Committee of Management.

This anxiety was increased by eleven of our children contracting typhoid fever in November last.

During the past year four deaths occurred in the Homes; one from Typhoid fever and three from Tuberculosis; and several children were sent back to their Reserves, on medical advice, afflicted with various Tubercular ailments, chiefly pulmonary.

Since January of the present year three deaths have occurred in the Homes from Tuberculosis; and two boys and one girl have been sent home on medical advice.

Appalled by these occurrences, the Committee of Management in February last nominated a Board
of medical officers to investigate as to the causes leading to so phenomenal a condition of affairs. The results of this investigation are embodied in the appended report.

Since receiving the report, a committee of practical business men, after careful personal inspection of the main building and premises, concur with the medical Board's views as to the necessity of, (1) a better and more up-to-date system of house drainage, (2) a safer water supply for domestic purposes, (3) increased recreation space for the pupils, better ventilation, and a general renovation of the main building.

With these facts before us we have no resource but to approach the Department. Our own means are more than exhausted for the purpose of maintenance. We are therefore petitioning solely upon the improvements and renovations necessary to justify the continued operation of the School.

We earnestly solicit the Department's counsel and assistance in surmounting the well nigh overwhelming difficulties with which we are confronted.

We are personally convinced that the renovations and improvements suggested are
imperatively demanded for the proper conduct of the work and as a safeguard for the good health of the 52 children now within our doors. We therefore confidently appeal to you to make such inquiries and to take such steps as may be necessary under the circumstances. In the meantime we anxiously await your reply.

Have the honor to remain

Very faithfully yours,

George Algoma

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The Bishop of Algoma has written the Department forwarding a copy of the report of a committee of medical men appointed by the Board of Management of the Shingwauk Home to examine into the sanitary condition of the premises.

The Bishop refers to an outbreak of typhoid fever which took place in November, last. This epidemic was brought to the Department's attention by the Principal at that time, and a newspaper cutting was inclosed, which showed that the water-supply of Sault Ste. Marie was impregnated with typhoid germs. The whole of the sewage of Sault Ste. Marie is carried down past the Home, which is only one and a-half miles from the town, while their own sewage is disposed of in the river by means of an open drain, which empties a short distance above the intake pipe for the school's water-supply. There is scarcely any current on the north bank of the river, and the accompanying plan of the Shingwauk grounds will show you the situation.

The committee recommend a thorough system of drainage, with closets, urinals and bath-rooms and a water-supply independent of the river from a deep well, pumped up by a wind-mill or other power. The bulk of the water used for drinking purposes is boiled, but the committee state that it is impossible to have instructions carried out by the scholars. Naturally they will use the water from the pipes when they have an opportunity.
and need it.

Tuberculosis is also prevalent in the school, and the committee have reported on the unsanitary condition of the building, and go fully into the changes and improvements in the building which should be made to remedy the existing state of affairs.

From this report it would appear that some radical changes and improvements should be made in the buildings and water-supply, but as the Bishop has furnished no estimate of the probable cost of these improvements, it would be necessary, before the Department could arrive at a definite understanding, to have a detailed estimate of the cost of putting this institution in a thoroughly sanitary condition, that is if the Department is willing to come to their assistance.

The Shingwauk Home is not the property of the Department, and, if it has to assume the cost of all the improvements suggested, it would be well that some definite understanding should be arrived at as to how the Department stands with regard to the ownership of the property. I think that they should either make it over to the Government or enter into an agreement to recoup the Department for the outlay that we have already gone to and the amount that the report will entail, in case they should at any time cease to carry on a school.

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Superintendent.

This week the Department sent a deputation in the interests of the Shingwauk Home, the Bishop of Algoma, Mr. King, the Principal, and Mr. Royce, M.P. The visit of the deputation was the outcome of certain correspondence which had taken place between the school authorities and the Department.

Typhoid fever has been very prevalent at the school and also tuberculosis, and the Board of Management deemed it important to have an examination of the buildings, the drainage and water supply, by competent men. Three physicians of standing went thoroughly over the ground and prepared a report. The recommendations included the provision of a supply of pure water, uncontaminated by the sewage from the town of Sault Ste. Marie and the Institution, which was thrown into Garden River above the intake pipe which supplies the Institution with water for all purposes.

The physicians also recommend a thorough system of drainage with usual modern conveniences. The Department, thoroughly alive to the needs of the case, requested the preparation of detailed plans and the estimate of the cost of making the required changes and improvements. The deputation presented such plans accompanied by the estimate. The changes appear to have been carefully planned and should, when carried out, provide the school with a proper system of drainage, necessary improvements in residential features and sanitation. It is proposed to provide water from an Artesian well for drinking purposes. The estimate for the work, excluding the well, is $7,955. The estimate appears to be a liberal one and the work can possibly be done for less. Detailed specifications have not yet been prepared, and a public competition may doubtless reduce the general cost. If the recommendation which I propose to make is approved of, it will be...

The most important question to be decided is how to provide funds. The estimates contain no special appropriation for the work except the item for "Unforeseen and miscellaneous" expenditure, but there is frequently an unexpended balance from the general appropriation for schools in Ontario and Quebec which might be utilized for such purpose. I think it quite feasible to provide the necessary amount from the existing appropriations and funds to be voted in the future, without increasing the general vote just mentioned, if it will be possible for the management of the school to arrange for carrying the cost or financing the outlay until April 1907.

We should be able to make an advance from the current appropriation. We will have a certain sum available from the 9 months' appropriation ended 31st March 1907, and the balance may be paid from our general vote for 1907-08. I am led to take this favorable view of the requests of the school management on account of the verbal acceptance by Bishop Thorntoe of the suggestion that he should acknowledge the contribution of the Department in such a binding manner that, if the school were closed or if its use as an Indian industrial school should ever cease, this Department will have a right to expect that there will be a proportionate refund for the present contributions. I would also say that the Boarding and Industrial schools in Ontario are in a different position from those in the West, and whatever doubt may be expressed with reference to the degree of usefulness in the latter, there is no doubt that these schools in Ontario have been for many years a large factor in civilizing the Indians. The Indians of Ontario and Quebec had arrived, some forty or fifty years ago, at a degree of civilization which rendered a system of education, including boarding schools, productive of the best results. These schools are now educating boys and girls to take their places in the white community, and it is the policy of these two (i.e., the Mohawk and the Shingwauk) to endeavour to place their pupils away from the reserves, where they can maintain themselves as do ordinary white citizens.

Referring to our conversation of a few days ago in regard to water supply for the Shingwauk Home which you desire to obtain from our system, and to your suggestion of laying a two inch galvanized iron pipe from this Company's main at the intersection of Queen and Pine Streets, through Pine Street to the waters edge of St. Mary's River and thence under water to a point outside the limits of the water lots and from that point on the bed of St. Mary's River to the river bank opposite the Shingwauk Home and thence in a trench to your buildings, I would say that the scheme which you suggest is entirely practicable and is probably the cheapest method by which you can obtain water from our mains for your ordinary requirements. Such a pipe should be able to supply about twenty Imperial gallons per minute at a reasonably good domestic pressure at your buildings, an amount which should be ample for all ordinary use. It would, however, be of practically no value for fire protection if fire plugs or hose lines were attached directly to the supply pipe. If connected to your fire tanks it would keep the tanks full so that...

The Deputy Superintendent General,

In connection with the alterations and additions which are now in progress at the Shingwauk Home, I beg to say that in the tenders received no provision was made for a water supply, to which particular attention was called in the report of the medical men appointed by the Board of Management of the Home to examine the sanitary condition of the premises, as the Principal was negotiating with the City water works with a view to obtaining an offer from them to connect the school with the city mains.

On the 9th inst., the Principal submitted an estimate furnished him by Mr. Sculland, who has the contract for the alterations and repairs to the buildings, to connect a private main with the city main, the total cost of which, including material, 7,500 ft. of 2" galvanized iron piping, labour, excavating, laying the pipes, etc., and the necessary plumbing and connections inside the building, would amount to $1,750. A sketch plan showing the direction the proposed pipe line would follow accompanied Mr. King's letter. Mr. Sculland's idea was to connect with the eastern end of the city main with a 3" pipe and carry the same at frost-proof depth submerged along the bottom of the St. Mary river to a point directly in front of the Shingwauk Home and then excavate and bring the pipe up to the buildings. To continue the main along the road would cost at least four times as much as to follow the proposed plan.

To-day Mr. King has sent me a letter addressed
to him by Mr. L. H. Davis, Chief Engineer of the Tagona Light Co., of Sault Ste. Marie, in regard to this proposition, from which you will see that he considers the scheme entirely practicable and the cheapest method by which water could be obtained from the city mains. He says that the scheme presents no difficulties which an experienced and reputable contractor should not easily be able to overcome, and that a 2" pipe should be able to supply about 30 imperial gallons per minute at a reasonably good domestic pressure at the school, an amount which would be ample for all ordinary uses.

As I before stated the water supply at the school is contaminated owing to the sewage and drainage from the buildings, which empties into a small bay or basin of the river in front of the school, and also by the town sewage entering the river at a higher level. Typhoid fever has been very prevalent in this school, caused by the use of this impure water, and the surest means of overcoming the difficulty would be to have connection with the city mains, which draw their supply from above the falls west of the city.

The only other alternative would be to sink wells, but it is questionable whether a sufficient supply of water could be obtained and there would be great uncertainty as to its quality, if found. In addition to this a pumping plant would be required to distribute the water throughout the buildings, and the expense would be fully equal to Mr. Soulland's estimate, and the results would be very doubtful.

You will see from Mr. King's letter, of the 25th inst., that, as to fire protection, they would still have
the two tanks in the roof of the main building, which have a capacity of 1,005 gallons and which can be filled by their present pumping plant at the river; and the 2" pipe would furnish an auxiliary supply in case of need.

The annual rate for the amount of water they would draw from the city would be about $100 to $135, while the cost of pumping up the impure water last year was $129.06.

If you approve of this plan, the school would be assured of a pure and permanent supply of water, and money the amount of XXXXX the Department is prepared to spend on this school to put it in a thoroughly sanitary condition will admit of this proposition being carried out.

Dear Sir:—

Your letter of the 10th inst in regard to water supply for the Shingwauk Home at this place, was duly received and I regret that through illness I have been obliged to delay replying to your letter until the present.

In reply to your proposition, namely, that this Company lay a main of suitable size along the highway from the end of its present main to the Shingwauk Home on the condition that the Indian Department guarantees 6% on the outlay, would say that the amount which you propose to guarantee, which I take to be a gross revenue of 6% on the cost of constructing the extension, would not be sufficient to warrant the Company in making the proposed extension, for the reason that when the expenses of operation and maintenance of pumping station and distributing system are taken into consideration, the Company would be operating the main to the Shingwauk Home at a very heavy loss under the condition you propose.

The mains which it would be necessary for us to lay in order to provide adequate fire protection in addition to domestic supply would be about 500 feet of 8" pipe and about 5000 feet of 6" pipe together with the requisite valves, hydrants and other...
The cost of construction would be approximately $7250.00, and the best proposition that we can make for laying such a main would be a guarantee from you of a gross revenue of $1000.00 per year. We would, of course, under such a guarantee from you, credit you with whatever charges were paid by other parties having services connected to this main, but when such charges equalled or more than made up the difference between our regular charges against the Department for water supply to the Shingwauk Home, the Department would pay the Company's regular charges for water.

Marie, Ontario, to have placed one or two hydrants at the Shingwauk Home for which our rate to the Town is $50.00 a hydrant per year, and which would help to reduce your liability upon your guarantee. It is of course far preferable to lay a main of proper size in the street instead of laying a small pipe on the bed of the river, as in the former case you would obtain ample fire protection which should give you better insurance rates. The Deputy Superintendent General,

Re water supply for Shingwauk Home.

While the alterations and improvements at the Shingwauk Home are nearly completed, the introduction of a supply of pure water is still unprovided for. The only sure means of obtaining this supply is by connection with the water works system of Sault Ste. Marie, and as the amount of money available for this purpose is limited, we will have to make such connection as the funds at the Department's disposal will permit.

An offer was made by Mr. Souland to connect with the city main by means of a 2" galvanized iron pipe for $1,750. Mr. Bray, who reported on this proposition, gave it as his opinion that 3,500 ft. of 2" pipe would make the delivery consist of a mere trickle of water, and that the laying of a pipe on the bed of the river would run great risk of displacement by anchors of boats, and for that reason he recommended that the water works company be asked to lay a main of suitable size along the highway in the usual manner to the Shingwauk Home. Acting on Mr. Bray's suggestion, the chief engineer of the Tayona Water and Light Co. was asked whether they would extend their main to the Shingwauk Home on a guarantee of 6% on the outlay.

A letter has just reached the Department from the chief engineer of this company, in which he states that the Department's offer would not be sufficient to warrant them in making the proposed extension. He estimates the cost of construction would be approximately $7,250, and that
the best proposition the Company could make for laying a main would be a guarantee from the Dept. of a gross revenue of $1,000 per year. The cost of this proposition kills it so far as the Dept. is concerned, as the total grant to this school is only $6,000, little more than half of which is ever earned by the school; therefore, the school could not pay $1,000 a year, and it would be establishing a bad precedent for the Dept. to guarantee any such sum.

The connection along the highway being impossible for the above reasons, there only remains the scheme to connect with the main by means of a pipe extended to the river and thence along the river bed to the front of the Shingwauk Home and from that point to the school by a trench below the frost line, which Mr. Sculland offers to do for $1,750, as before stated.

In order to satisfy myself as to the correctness of Mr. Bray's statement that a mere trickle of water would only be delivered at the school out of a 2" pipe, I wrote to Mr. King, the Principal, on my own account to find out what power was at the back of the main. He informs me that the Sault water works system maintains a pressure of 95 pounds by direct pumping, and that the main it is proposed to tap is 8" in diameter and that the pressure at that point is 95 pounds. I also asked him as to the danger of floating ice displacing the pipe, and he informs me that Mr. Davis, the water works engineer, is of opinion that there is no such danger. He says that there are no landing places along this particular shore line to induce vessels to come in and that the pipe would be carried to deep water below the ice formation. After writing Mr. King I went to the pump-house here and got the opinion of the engineer in charge as to the supply of water that a 2" pipe should give and the danger of its being affected by frost or being displaced by moving ice or small boats. He told me that, while
a 3" pipe would furnish a fair supply of water for drinking purposes, for an institution the size of the Shingwauk Home he would recommend that a 3" pipe be substituted, so as to avoid any danger of shortage. With regard to the practicability of laying such a length of pipe, nearly 7000 ft., under water, I have the opinion of Mr. McKinley, the leading plumber of this city, who says that the scheme is quite feasible. The cost of a 2" pipe, as quoted by Mr. Soulland, is 16 cents a foot, while the cost here is 15 cents. A 3" pipe here costs 33 cents, which is a fraction over double the price of a 2" pipe. The difference in price of installing a 3" pipe and a 2" pipe would be about $1,400. This would make the total cost of connection by means of a 3" pipe come to about $6,200 at the outside, which is $4,050 less than the continuation of the main along the highway would cost. As regards the question of fire protection, the school would not be dependent on the city water works, as they have a pumping plant of their own at the mill on the river bank, which is already connected with the tanks in the building.

If funds can be furnished for laying a 3" pipe along the river bed, as suggested by Mr. Soulland, I do not see that the Dept. could do better than adopt this plan.

Sir:

Re water supply for Shingwauk Home.

I regret the necessity of reopening this question, but in view of a further proposition Mr. Sculland has just made to me I feel bound to do so.

Mr. Sculland now advocates bringing the 3 inch water pipe from the town mains along the main road entirely to the Shingwauk Home, and abandoning the river bed altogether. He anticipates, I believe, difficulties in cofferdamming and working in the water which the lateness of the season and weather generally are likely to entail, and realizing his responsibility would prefer, though more costly, to excavate along the main road entirely and thus permanently safeguard all risks.

To enable him to do this he asks the Department to allow him an additional $500. to assist in additional cost for excavation.

I do not think the request unreasonable and would strongly urge a favorable consideration.

Anticipating the Department's acceptance of this latter proposition I immediately sought the consent of the Sault Ste Marie Town council to the laying of the pipe along the main road. The corporation's assent is embodied in the attached memorandum. The work of laying the pipe at frost proof depth not less than five feet would be subject to the town engineer's inspection and approval. As time means much just now may I ask the Department to wire me its decision.

The Acting Deputy Superintendent General,

On September 6th, a tender, by wire, was received from Mr. J. T. Sculland, of Sault Ste. Marie, through the Principal of the Shingwauk Home, offering to connect the Sault Ste. Marie water mains with the Shingwauk Home by means of a three inch pipe, to be laid along the river bed, for the sum of $3,025, including material, labour, plumbing, etc. On the 7th inst., this offer was accepted on certain conditions, embodied in a letter of that date, the acceptance of which terms and conditions was to be made in writing by Mr. Sculland.

There is nothing on file to show that Mr. Sculland accepted the contract on the terms mentioned, but on the 11th inst., Mr. King advised the Department that he would forward Mr. Sculland's written agreement, as well as a certificate as to the sufficiency of water that would be conveyed by a three inch pipe.

Material was purchased and the work started, and Mr. King, in a letter dated the 11th inst., asked for an advance of $600 on account of the contract, which was granted.

A letter has been received today from Mr. King, stating that Mr. Sculland now advocates bringing the pipe from the town mains along the main road and abandoning the river bed altogether, owing to trouble he anticipates in cofferdamming and working in the water on account of the lateness of the season. He offers to lay the pipe at frost-proof depth, not less than five feet, subject to the inspection and approval of the town engineer, along the highway to the Home for an additional $200, or $3,225 in all, and the
permission of the town council to lay the pipe along the road has been obtained.

In the early part of the negotiations the Chief Engineer of the Tagona Water and Light Co. submitted an estimate of the cost of extending the city main to the Home by the road, which amounted to $7,250. This was, however, for 500 ft. of 6" pipe and 8000 ft. of 6" pipe, together with necessary valves, hydrants and fittings to supply sufficient water for domestic purposes and also for adequate fire-protection. The best proposition they could make for laying this main was a guarantee from the Department of a gross revenue of $1,000 per annum, to which the Department could not consent.

In comparison with the above Mr. Scullands offer appears to be remarkably fair, and it is for the Department to decide whether it shall be accepted or not.

A.J. MacKenzie
With reference to the letter from Mr. King of the 18th instant, and the water supply for the Shingwauk, I beg to state that the Department is apparently committed to have a pipe-line laid from the town of Sainte-Marie by Mr. J.T. Soulliere at the cost of $3,000. The said pipe-line to be laid in the river. The contractor now finds that the difficulty of coffer-damming is very great. I may say that the expense of coffer-damming from the shore to a depth of five feet of water in any locality where the bed of the river recedes gradually is very great.

On the part of the Department, I beg to state, as in a previous memorandum, that the laying of the pipe in the bed of the river is very objectionable, as it liable to disturbance at any time. The laying of a pipe on land is incomparably preferable. As the contractor asks the trifling extra sum of $200, I think the Department should agree to pay the extra sum of $200, without hesitation.

I desire to place on record, although too late for action, that I think the whole of this business has been pushed forward without proper investigation. It appears from the correspondence and memoranda that it is held that there is no other way of furnishing pure water to the Home but by connecting with the Water Works system of the Town. I do not know the locality, but it appears to me that inquiry should have been made as to whether there is any other source of supply, especially in the direction of a good well properly protected, or an artesian...
well, either of which could be sunk and fitted with a wind-
or hot-air engine
mill for possibly about one-third of the cost of bringing
water from the town.

The contract and the specifications are not
on file, I think Mr. King should be asked to forward them.

Memorandum

For Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

I beg to inform you that as instructed by your official letter, dated December 5, last, I made an inspection of Shingwauk and Wawanoosh Homes, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., on March 6, last, and to report as follows:

The school, a stone building of good architectural design, thoroughly English in type, erected on the north side of the main street of the city with a pleasing suburban view of the river and landscape and surrounded by well kept grounds of considerable extent, is in appearance, at least, an ideal home school. That it is so, is apparent, as the principal and his family are making the personal welfare of each pupil their especial interest, and, I firmly believe, that under the direction of the Rev. Principal that this school is again destined to achieve good results.

The building, from the exterior, is almost unique in its rustic beauty, being erected of native field or boulder stone, hammer dressed, roughly and flushed up with lime mortar to even face.

The main building, 36' by 134', with extension on either end, the left being 25' by 35' and Principal's residence on the right, 27' by 40' and also extension at rear, 26' by 36', contains on ground floor—entrance hall, dining-room, pupils and staff, kitchen for pupils and staff, recreation room, each for boys and girls, lavatories, each for boys and girls, staff laboratory, shoemaker's shop, office, clothing room, corridor and three boiler rooms as well as Principal's residence. On first floor are—the school rooms Nos. 1 and 2 boys and girls recrea-
tion-rooms, sewing-rooms staff sitting-room 7 bedrooms, clothing-room and Principal's residence.

The upper floor contains 3 dormitories for girls, 4 for boys, 2 clothing rooms and 2 bed or monitor's rooms, adjoining boys' and girls' dormitories.

Interior arrangement—

The arrangement of the interior, while roomy and probably convenient, is not of modern school type and appears to have been erected in sections, more care having been exercised in the preserving of the outside architectural appearance than in producing an ideal interior for the purpose for which it is used. For this reason considerable floor space is not fully utilized. The ceiling also being low requires a considerable excess of wall and floor space to provide the required cubical air area. This in connection with the irregular exterior providing an unduly large proportion of wall space and floor surface over cubical area makes the building an expensive one to heat and ventilate satisfactorily.

Class-rooms—

The class-rooms are 33' by 38' by 9½' and has a floor area of 1254 and a cubical area of 12226, accommodates on floor 72 pupils; but air space for 50 only. A smaller class-room, boys, 23' by 34' by 9½' has a floor area 7827 and a cubical area of 7627 accommodates on floor 48 and air space for 30'.

The outside school class-room has a floor space available 29' by 56' with floor area and air space to accommodate 90-95 pupils.

Dormitories, Girls—

Girls' dormitories No. 1, has a floor space 31'6" by 18'9" by 9'9" equals air space for 11 pupils.

No. 2, has a floor area of 662½ sq. ft. and cu. area of 8400 accommodation for 17 pupils.

No. 3, has a floor space of 14' by 22', has a cubical area of 2028 ft. accommodates 4 pupils or a total of 32 girls.
Boys dormitories-

Boys dormitories are 4 in number, the first being 51' by 21' by 9'3", contains 9907 cu. ft., equals accommodation for 20.

No. 2, 19½' by 22' by 9'3" has a cubical area of 3968 ft. accommodation for 8 pupils.

No. 3, 18' by 21½' has a cubical area of 3580, equals accommodation for 7 pupils.

No. 4, 12' by 27' has a cubical area of 2897 and will accommodate 6 pupils or a total dormitory accommodation (boys and girls) for 73 pupils.

All of the dormitories are fairly well lighted and airy and owing to the low ceilings have a floor and wall space greatly in excess of actual requirements.

Recreation rooms-

The girls' recreation room on ground floor 22' by 22' is well lighted, airy and convenient and has lavatory adjoining. In addition the girls have a sewing room on floor above which is used for recreation purposes and is also conveniently situated, airy and well lighted.

The boys' recreation room on ground floor 23' by 27' is in the north east corner of the building, and while convenient is not as well lighted as the girls'. The large hall (separate building) 60' by 30' however, is both well lighted, airy and fitted up as a gymnasium, some of the boys being very proficient in these exercises and all thoroughly enjoy their recreation there.

Lavatories-

The lavatory for girls 9' by 22' adjoins girls' recreation room, has 4 W.C.'s and basins.

Boys lavatory 12' by 22' adjoins boys' recreation room, has 4 W.C.'s and trough type urinal, 5 basins and boiler for heating hot water for bathing purposes.

Private lavatory-

There is also a lavatory for staff as well as a private bathroom in residence of Principal.
Sick room-

There is no sick or infirmary room in the school, other than private bedrooms, which are used for temporary illness.

Hospital-

There is an isolation hospital within a short distance of the school on opposite side of street, containing 4 rooms, with attendants' residence attached. There are no sanitary fixtures installed.

Drains-

The drainage system is sanitary and apparently in good condition.

Ventilation-

The building is ventilated by overhead or ceiling ventilation, these can be cut off from ceiling, carried down on face of walls to floors and will partly ventilate rooms where located. Additional ventilation will be required for class-rooms and dormitories to enable the building to fully comply with Department's requirements.

Heating-

The building is heated by hot water system three hot water boilers being located in separate positions in the building; and those while answering their purpose are not as effective for heating purposes as they would have been, if differently installed. The most effective system of heating for an irregular building, of this extent, is undoubtedly low pressure steam.

Bedrooms-

There are 4 staff bedrooms (excluding Principal's residence) on first floor in addition to a large staff sitting room on first flat and 2 monitor's bedrooms on dormitory flat, all being of good size, airy and well lighted.

Clothes room-

There are 2 clothes rooms for the storing of wardrobes, etc.,
