one each for boys and girls with other rooms available should more room be required at any time.

Principal's residence—

The Principal's residence is attached to and partly surrounds one corner of the school building, contains on first floor, hall, parlour, dining-room, kitchens, three bedrooms, bath-room, corridor and shed; and on ground floor, Principal's office, store-room, boiler-room, coal-room, shed and passage.

General—

All of the buildings enumerated herein are substantial and in fairly good condition some minor repairs being necessary, only such, however, as are usually looked for in any building which has been in constant use for a prolonged period.

It will be necessary to install a good system of ventilation in the building, particularly in the dormitories and classrooms as owing to the building being erected of stone, with thick walls and wide reveals, less sunlight is diffused in the interior; and also owing to the stone walls, especially in the very warm weather, condensation is rapid and general throughout the building, except where fires are constantly kept going.

It will also be necessary to install 3 shower baths, each for boys and girls, in their bathrooms and seven basins for boys' and five for girls' lavatories to fully complete their sanitary equipment. In every other way the school will comply with Department's requirements.

Recommendation—

I would recommend that providing six shower baths and twelve basins are installed and a system of ventilation put in dormitories, class-rooms, etc., and isolation hospital put in good condition and sanitary conveniences installed, so as to fully comply with Department's requirements, that the building be ranked as in the first class.

Basins—

Provide also and fix in position directed in isolation hospital, two of the Sanitary Ideal enamelled iron lavatories (Plate E. 124) with slab bowl, overflow and back all in one piece, nickle-plated waste plug, coupling and rubber stopper, No. nickle plated compression cocks, supply pipes and traps, with waste and vent to wall.

Bath—

Place where required and directed in hospital one of the Sanitary A. Express (Plate E. 1.) Porcelain enamelled cast iron baths with three inch rolled rim and having nickle waste and overflow pipes, trap and connected with waste and soil pipe. The cocks to be single nickle-plated compression for hot and cold water.

Shower baths—

Provide and fix in position shown each for boys and girls, three Standard ceiling N.P. showers with self-closing valve, chain and pull (Plate 483) Standards Manufacturing Co's Catalogue, Pittsburg.

Provide also at wall where hot and cold water connects leading to showers N. P. compression valves to each for the purpose of controlling the temperature of the water in showers.

The mains for supply to showers in both hot and cold water will be of three-quarter galvanized iron pipes.

Water closets—

Provide and fix in position requiring it in isolation hospital one or the Ontario Syphon Jet closets with plain natural oak seat and oak copper lined tank (high), with ball cock and syphon action. Closets to have brass floor flanges, rubber gaskets, etc., complete and to be connected to cast iron soil pipes with brass collar and ferrule.

Soil pipes—

All cast iron soil pipes shall be four inches inside diameter, sound smooth on the inside, free from cracks or sand holes and eight lbs. in weight per lineal foot.

All joints in cast iron will be made with oakum and molten lead. The joints to be full hub joints and the metal to be well caulked in with hammer and calking iron.

All connections between lead and iron will be made with brass ferrules and thimble caulked as before specified and ferrule attached to lead with a good wipe joint.

Break syphon—

All fixtures specified herein to have break syphon which will be one size smaller than trap ventilated, the vents to be connected to soil pipes where practicable otherwise to be carried and attached to nearest chimney which is in constant use and carried through roof.
Water pipes—

The water pipes from supply to fixtures in hospital to be main three-quarter inches branches by one-half pipe of galvanized iron.

General—

The work specified herein to be done in a good sanitary and workmanlike manner and is to be complete and connect with plumbing equipment and drainage system now in, without additional expenses and is intended to include everything necessary for the full and complete installation of the fixtures enumerated herein.

Ventilation.

Hospital ventilation—

The isolation hospital will have ducts of galvanized iron carried from floor line of each infirmary room carried above ceiling, connected and attached to chimney and carried through roof and finished with a rotary ventilating top or other well-known make of force draught ventilating top.

School ventilation—

The ventilation ducts now in the building and opening from the ceiling will be cut off at wall ceiling line and extended to floor line and having Louvre Registers without face plates to each.

The registers to be of the full capacity size of ducts for each.

Provide for dormitories and large class-rooms three additional ventilating ducts, carried up through roof with registers of sufficient capacity as marked on plan to thoroughly ventilate these rooms, having covered ventilating tops of approved

The whole of the work to be done in a good and workmanlike manner and is intended to include everything necessary and requisite to complete the work specified.

Rev. Sir,

I beg to inform you that the architect who inspected the Shingwauk and Nawaneh Homes, Sault Ste. Marie, on the 6th March last, has made his report to the Department and which is very favourable to the Homes. Generally commending the school and the work done there; but states that the building, while substantial, is not of a modern school type having apparently been erected in sections, with very low ceilings, thus wasting floor space and making the school a difficult one to heat and ventilate satisfactorily.

It is noted that while the building is sufficiently roomy and provides ample accommodation for 73 pupils and staff, in addition to a convenient Principal's residence, that the arrangement of rooms is not as advantageous for boarding school purposes as the Department advises for the newer schools. However, as this is principally a matter of convenience for those in authority there and as a rearrangement of rooms cannot readily be made, without a very considerable expenditure, the building must suffice as at present arranged.

It is also stated that the sanitary arrangements and ventilation are deficient and that it will be necessary

July 19th, 1915.

MEMORANDUM -

Mr. Scott -

SAULT STE. MARIE.

I proceeded to Sault Ste. Marie on the 29th ultimo, and on Wednesday the 30th ultimo, Mr. McNabb and I visited Garden River Reserve and the Chingwauk Home. While at the Garden River Reserve we visited Mr. Hardyman at the Protestant school, and I wish to draw attention to the needs at this school. Their supply of water is not satisfactory, and a new well should be sunk outside of the building, the present one being in the basement. This simply involves the driving of a pipe and water will presumably be found at no great depth. A new pump should also be provided.

The school building is in need of painting and the interior of the building should be halosanized. A hard-wood floor should also be laid in the class-room.
The surrounding grounds are, as usual, in excellent condition and a splendid object lesson for the Indians. Mr. Hardyman has quite a large lawn, and I think he should be furnished with a lawn mower, and I would recommend that the Agent be authorized to purchase one for him and to have the work above mentioned done.

I visited nearly all the locations on the reserve to see the farming operations which the Agent has been conducting this summer on a somewhat large scale. In connection with each house there is a garden plot planted and some of the Indians have a considerable area in crop. Mr. McNabb is very enthusiastic about this work, and if they should be fortunate enough to obtain good results this year, I am sure that he will have very little difficulty in increasing the scope of the work another season. The surveyors were at work subdividing the eastern portion of the reserve which the Agent hopes will be located for farming purposes by a number of the younger people of the band.

At the Shingwauk Home I found that the lighting system had been installed and was working
satisfactorily. They were at work on the addition, which is to be used as a laundry. The walls which were of masonry work were very nearly completed. They hope to have the building ready for occupation early in August. The laundry machinery is on hand.

With regard to the lighting system, the estimated cost was $540.00, but Mr. Fuller purchased some of the fixtures, etc., from a merchant in the Soo, who was retiring from business and in calling for prices had his quotations made subject to the use of this material, by so doing he made a considerable reduction in the cost, which was only $331.00, an approximate saving of $209.00. Mr. Fuller asks that he be allowed to spend a sum not exceeding this amount in the purchase of a motor for use in the laundry. They had contemplated using their gasoline engine, and of course the motor would be a great convenience to them.

In view of the excellent work that Mr. Fuller is doing at this institution, I think the Department would be justified in allowing him to make this purchase, and I would recommend it. There is quite an improvement on the buildings, surrounding grounds and the farm since I last was
at the institution, and considering the difficulties with which Mr. Fuller has had to contend ever since taking charge of this institution, I think he is to be highly commended.

A.F. MacGregor
Ottawa, August 4, 1915.

Rev. Sir,

Mr. MacKenzie of this Department, who visited your school last month, reports that in connection with the installation of the lighting system you effected an approximate saving of $209.00 out of the appropriation of $540.00 which was made for that purpose and he recommends that you be allowed to expend a sum not exceeding the amount saved in the purchase of a motor for use in the laundry.

In view of the satisfactory report made by Mr. MacKenzie, the Department will allow you to expend a sum not exceeding $209.00 in the purchase of a motor.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. MOLLAN

Dear Sir -

Dr. Orr, Director of the Provincial Museum, who recently visited your institution, reports the absence of screens on the windows of the school-room and dormitories.

While this is equipment that should be furnished by the management of the school, I am disposed under the circumstances to give you some assistance. We shall pay for the wire and lumber necessary, if you will undertake to make the screens for these windows.

I was surprised to learn that the windows were being kept shut, especially in the dormitories and class-rooms during the summer season. This must be most injurious to the health of the children and must be remedied without delay. Kindly, therefore, give the matter your immediate attention.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of June 23rd received, also previous letter on same subject, and in answer I beg to say that since your first letter I have given the matter very careful consideration and find that I have come to this decision that it would not be wise to take off the upper storey but to re-roof the building as it is, re-top the chimneys, take off the little tower, take away the old steps and re-build with stone and cement, repair windows and cover outside with wire screens, strong wire, and paint outside.

There are two reasons for leaving the building as it is. The first of these is, the building contains a Tablet which states that the building was erected in memory of "Chief Shingwask".

The second is that in view of the fact that we are to organize Boy Scouts and Cadets, the upper floor would be very useful and would be a fine room for any entertainment when we would have visitors.

With this suggestion, I have made a careful and close estimate of the material and cost of same and attached please find same.

All of which is humbly submitted,
Yours truly,
"Benj. P. Fuller".

Rev. Sir:

Dr. Westgate, Winnipeg, has forwarded a copy of your communication to him of the 27th ultimo, regarding the repairs that are required to the drill hall in connection with the Shingwauk Home. The estimate made by you as to the cost of the material required has also been received.

You are hereby authorized to have the repairs required to this building carried out, and the total cost of the material and labour required should not exceed approximately $450.00.

It will be necessary, in the purchase of all material, to obtain competitive prices from a number of firms handling the material required, and the purchase should, in each case, be made from the firm quoting you the lowest price.

Properly certified accounts, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of the material, to which should be attached a memorandum showing the names of the firms asked to quote a price and the prices quoted.

To The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

I count it a privilege to write you at the suggestion of our Indian Agent, Mr. A. D. McNabb, regarding what seems to be, and was to a degree a mistake on my part in regard to the improvements and repairs at the Shingwauk Home.

All through our term of office, thirteen years, we have felt the great need of toilets connected with the dormitories located on the third story of the main building. These in use were all on the ground floor, and in case of sickness, or when we had, as is always the case, pupils who required watching in regard to the condition of their beds, it was no small responsibility lacking the necessary conveniences in or near the dormitory.

When in 1910 or 1911, the Department required sanitary improvement in the matter of bath tubs and wash basins, the work was paid for from the Per. Cap. and we could not possibly afford the extra toilets then. We were beginning to feel the strain of the work when war time and high prices began to effect, and the matter of improvements and even repairs had to be dismissed for the time.

Then came the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, and in them we saw a possible chance to get the really necessary repairs made, and the improvements installed. Again the Society informed us in a letter dated Winnipeg, Sept. 27th, signed Dr. T. B. R. Westgate Field Secretary for the M.S.C.C., that one thousand dollars ($1000.00) was...
appropriated by the Indian Department; four hundred and fifty dollars to be spent in repairs to the building called the Drill Hall, and the balance five hundred and fifty, to be expended in either one or both of the urgent needs explained by the Principal, i.e., installation of toilets and repairs to furnace.

We then began and went as far as possible with the repairs to the Hall. Then the installation of the toilets, and then the repairs to the furnace. This furnace has never been in use since we have been in charge. First—Because by some accident the system became filled with water when not in use and froze so badly we could not think of repairs. Second—We, for several years, procured our own fuel by cutting wood, and as the part of damaged system used to heat the Principal's residence we could by installing small stoves do without the heat from this third furnace, thus delaying the cost of repairs and saving on fuel. Then when we were informed that the Department would be willing to assist us and $1000.00 set apart for that purpose we began the repairs, doing all we could to help in the unskilled work, opening drains and sewers etc.

But there being no possible means of obtaining an estimate of the extent of breaks in pipes we were forced to proceed and to repair and test until we obtained a complete repair. I have to confess we were in a very anxious condition of mind as to the cost considering the uncertain manner in which we had to do the work and I went to explain to our Indian Agent, also expressing my willingness to have the overdraft in the cost of repairs deducted from my salary, if the Department would settle the account.

I wish to express my lasting gratitude to the Indian Department, and to the kind consideration of Mr. McNabb for the

PRESENTMENT of GRAND JURY

GENERAL SESSIONS OF THE PEACE FOR THE DISTRICT OF ALGOMA

To His Honour Judge Stone
Judge of the District of Algoma

We, the members of the Grand Jury for the General Sessions of the Peace for the District of Algoma held at the City of Sault Ste Marie commencing on the 29th day of May, 1923, beg to make the following presentment,

We desire to congratulate Your Honour on the able manner in which you have carried out the onerous duties of your high office which you have so efficiently filled for so many years, and trust that you may be able to continue your duties as Judge of this important District for many years to come.

In accordance with your instructions we visited various Institutions in and contiguous to the District Gaol on McNab Street and public assistance and beg to report

the District Gaol on McNab Street is in good condition and everything was found very satisfactory. We have also visited the interior arrangement and facilities and have the opinion however that the vacant land near the Gaol, property on the west and cultivated by the prisoners as a garden, should be enclosed and the whole property suitably fenced. We recommend the erection of a separate building for the use of the Gaol, to house temporarily the prisoners and be provided as soon as possible.

CANADA
At the District House of Refuge there were fifty four inmates. Everything here was found clean and sanitary and reflected great credit on the capable management of this useful Institution. The third flat should be at once completed and equipped and all the floors should be oiled and an elevator installed.

At the Children's Shelter Home everything was also found in excellent condition, reflecting the utmost credit on Mr. and Mrs. Cornell who were in charge, the discipline and care of the helpless children finding a temporary home there, leaving nothing to be desired.

The Algoma Home for Indian Children commonly known as the Shingwauk Home contained eighty two children of both sexes. Considering the length of time since this building was erected, everything was found in good shape but there should be a new roof to the main building and numerous minor interior repairs thereto to place same in the best condition for the purposes for which it was erected. The barn is in poor condition and should be raised and placed on a new foundation and have cement floors constructed, a new roof and proper inside equipment installed, as these matters have a great influence on the boys attending this Institution. We cannot too highly praise the work of Rev. Mr. Fuller, the able Superintendent of this Home.

At the Plummer Memorial Hospital there were fifteen patients all of whom were receiving the best attention possible, the equipment here being very modern in every respect.

At the General Hospital there were thirty patients and every detail here was found to be in excellent shape and up to date. We found there an Indian Child two years of age which was sub-normal and born out of wedlock and has since birth remained at the Hospital but should be sent to the Sick Children's Hospital at Toronto for proper treatment.
We desire to congratulate the District on the very complete accommodation provided by the Province in the New Court House in respect to which we can suggest no improvement.

In conclusion we desire to thank Your Honour for the very instructive address given us in connection with our duties as Grand Jurors, and the various Court Officials for their assistance to us in respect to the various matters with which we have had to deal.

August 17, 1923.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Canon Gould, General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, and the Superintendent of Indian Education visited, this week, the Shingwauk Home, an Indian Residential School near Sault Ste. Marie. Mr. Ferrier reports that Canon Gould and the Rev. Principal have drawn his attention to certain repairs and replacements to buildings, that should be undertaken without delay. 28,000 shingles are required for the roof of the main building; 65 bbls. of cement are required to replace the old wooden floor in the barn; a metal sheeted roof is also needed for the barn. Our officer made an arrangement with the Rev. Principal that, if the materials were supplied and two carpenters were employed, the school staff and larger boys would give their help and that gravel, stone and rough lumber would be supplied by the school.

The cost of the materials and the wages for two carpenters would be in the neighborhood of $950. I should be pleased to have your authority to authorize the repairs. This school has received very little assistance from Parliamentary Appropriation, other than the per capita grant. The Principal has done splendid work and is quite competent to supervise the activities that I have recommended. Funds are available in the Vote for Indian Education.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. McNabb:

I have to authorize you to undertake certain repairs and replacements to buildings at the Shingwauk Home. The Superintendent of Indian Education reports that a portion of the roof of the main building and the girls' play room should be re-shingled; that a metal sheeted roof and cement floor are required for the barn; that the granary should be moved near the barn and made into a pig pen; and that the old bake house and ice house should be removed to the back of the main building, and the materials used in the construction of a root house.

You are authorized to purchase, after securing competitive prices, 25,000 shingles, 85 bbls. of cement, sufficient corrugated sheets or metal shingles to cover the barn, and $50 worth of lumber for the root house, barn door, etc. You are also authorized to engage a Mr. MacNab, whom Mr. Perrier states is a competent foreman, to oversee these activities, and one other competent carpenter. One dollar and seventy cents, respectively, per hour will be allowed as wages; time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept. It is understood that all gravel, stone and rough lumber will be supplied by the Reverend Principal. Further, the larger boys at the school will be expected to do all hauling and unskilled labour.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have had a talk with our farmer and his wife regarding the house they wish to move into, and I find that they are quite willing to do as we always have done. Try to make it as comfortable as possible and with as little expense as actually necessary.

If you think we could put in the simple fixtures for a bathroom, and a little sink in the kitchen, a new top floor in the kitchen, we, with the help the farmer can give, will fit the house to quite satisfy them for the present.

There is no doubt in my mind about the fact that we ought to do it for them, and if the management was the same as in the past, I would go at it and do it, but we cannot do that under the present system.

There is also the fact to be considered, that Mr. Hayes is now an experienced help to us, understands the detail of the school, and also the members of the staff, all of which goes to make an efficient worker.

We have finished all the re-roofing, and more than we laid out to do, this we were able to do, by having some shingles left over, and by carefully taking off the old shingles, and using them in another place. We still have the barn floor to do, and as soon as the man McNabb is ready and we can haul the gravel and sand, we start at that.

Please advise me regarding the house repairs. How to proceed.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal

Sir:

The Principal of the Shingwauk Home requests that certain repairs be carried out to the house which is to be occupied by the farmer and his wife, in order that it may be made comfortable for their use.

I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase of the simple fixtures, required for the fitting up of a bathroom, also for the purchase of a sink and piping for the kitchen. Competitive prices should be obtained and the purchase of these supplies made from the firm quoting the lowest price. It is not intended that any undue expenditure be incurred, as only the most simple fittings should be supplied. If the school authorities are not able to do the work of installing these fixtures, you may engage the services of a competent plumber for the purpose, at the prevailing rate of wages.

A new top floor is needed in the kitchen. You may purchase and have delivered at the school the necessary material for the purpose. The work of laying the floor is to be carried out by the farmer, with the assistance of the older pupils.

Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the fixtures for the bathroom and kitchen, as well as for the labour and material for the top floor in the kitchen. These purchases should receive your early attention and the work completed as soon as possible, so that this house may be placed in a comfortable condition for the farmer and his wife.

Sir,

I beg to inclose this letter explaining the Account from Dunseath & Mc Clary. You will notice that I deducted $16.00 from the A/c rendered by them, my reason for doing so is as follows. When I received your letter No 13-0-5 Dated Oct 6th/23 I went down to the Shingwauk to consult with Mr Fuller and I saw Dunseath & Mc Clary's men at work at the Farmers House, I asked Mr Fuller if he had started those men and he told me he had not, but that he had been talking to Mr Dunseath about the work and when he saw them at work he thought I had started them. They had some material on the ground and I told Mr Fuller to stop them as I had to have competitive prices on the material. I tried several plumbers to get them to do the work, they were too busy so I asked Dunseath what he would charge me per hour for Eddie Pim and he said he would give me Pim but that he must have a helper. He agreed for 90¢ per hour for Pim and 50¢ per hour for Helper. I could not do any better so I told him to go ahead. Dunseath claims that it was one Dollar per hour for Pim. As I made no written agreement with him considering his word as good as mine I am allowing him what he says.

You will notice in the Account where I marked with a Cross that those amounts are for the 3rd man Mr Dunseath himself, it seems he drove the men to work every morning and went after them at night. I made no arrangement that the Department would have to pay for their transportation. I called up Mr Dunseath and told him we would have to take off his wages as only 2 men were hired. No doubt he will write you in reference to this matter, and those are the facts as above stated.

This Firm have done a lot of work at the Shingwauk and there was no check on them whether the a/c was right or wrong and I suppose they thought it was still the same.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th Instant No. 13-0-5A, in reference to J. M. Nicholson's account for labor at the Shingwauk Home.

When Mr. Ferrier was here he made arrangements with Mr. Mc Nabb, a carpenter to do the work. Mc Nabb was away at Blind River at the time we wanted to cement the Barn. I tried several masons to get them to do the job, they were all too busy. I got this man Nicholson to do the work; his price was just the same as was to be paid to Mc Nabb & helper. This man is a practical man at laying cement he used his own tools and he made a first class job as Mr. Fuller can verify. He worked 8 hours per day when in the City @ $1.25 per hour and he asked that price from me. I explained the situation to him and told him we expected 10 hours per day, and that I would allow him what Mc Nabb was getting $1.00 per hour for himself and 70¢ for his assistant. That arrangement was the very best I could do and Mr. Fuller was well satisfied with the work done. I have done my best to get all work entrusted to me done as cheaply and economically as I possibly could.

Hoping this explanation is satisfactory and that you will send Mr. Nicholson his Cheque as soon as possible, as I told him he would get his Cheque within 10 days after he got through with the work.

Dear Sir;

For some time we have known that our Fire Hose was of very little use, having been here for years, and while we exercise the utmost care in avoiding fires, still we can never feel safe with the hose we have. Fires have occurred, which by quick action have always been controlled.

I am enclosing a sample of the hose now in use, the sample will be more accurate than the measurement that we could send. We require three pieces, each 30 feet in length, and with no fittings, as we have the unions and the nozzles.

All the fires that we have had occurred from sparks falling on to the roof from the chimneys, and thirty feet length enables us to reach such places where these may occur.

May we ask for our general guidance, what repairs, and improvements The Dept. are prepared to give to our School, when done in proper order, and at the proper time. We have now an account for plumbing that was necessary to have done at once, and our Society Commission say that we should try to get the Dept to pay it. The idea of trying to get them to pay it does not appeal to us. We would rather know the attitude as a rule in this matter. No matter how careful we may be there is always some unseen thing that may happen. We shall be thankful for a consideration of the matters referred to in this letter.

Obediently Yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I am only too willing in the report you have asked for. I regret very much that I have defaulted so long. But to tell the facts of the case, I can give a very good idea or knowledge of what funds our school is receiving from the Indian department, but have no knowledge of other grants from other sources, all these go straight to the Missionary Society, as do also the Per Cap from the Department at Ottawa. So that when you receive the report, you will understand why I have not given any account of small grants, such as Sunday Schools and the grants for the support of pupils, which is undertaken by many of our Church congregations and others.

All our requirements are requisitioned for to the Missionary Society, and all bills are paid by them, so that we have no deficits such as we used to have. The Society take all monies, and are responsible for all debts. The salaries are all paid by them, but the Women's Auxiliary of the church supply all money to pay female workers in the Indian Boarding Schools.

Two years ago we had a new roof put on the large Class-room and drill Hall, and that is the only repairs we have done since the Missionary Society took over the management of the Indian Schools, and our buildings are in sore need of repairs and paint.

We are often afraid that we may be asked why we are neglecting these things, and here we would like to state our reasons.

1st.) We wish to do certain repairs, and paint certain buildings, and we requisition the Missionary Society for these materials needed, and the reply we get is to apply to the Government for them.

2nd.) If we are correct, the Indian Department have said that they will do all major repairs and improvements. We are not able to distinguish where the minor expenditure would end, or where the major expenditures would begin. That we did think was the meaning of the Departments letter. That they would become responsible for any important improvements, but other minor repairs, we would be responsible for. We would like to have this matter made more plain to us.

3rd.) We have buildings to repair, and improve. All the buildings should be painted. We need new floors in our Hall, and our farmers house. If we could make an estimate of these, they would total more than one thousand dollars. Our fences are needing new wire, and this we are requested to ask the Department for, and so we have gone along doing without, until now we must attend to these repairs.

We are stating these matters here, but not asking for them, until we know where we may ask them from.

We are always willing, and do try to do with as little as possible, but the buildings and grounds should appear a credit to the work we are trying to do.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

When Dr. Eastgate, Field Secretary of the M.S.C.O., visited our School some time ago, we talked over some repairs and improvements that we would like to make as soon as we were able or prepared to do so. Now we are in receipt of a communication, copy of a letter sent to The Indian Agent Mr. Sims referring to these matters.

Mr. Sims called me and we talked the matter over, with the result we decided to write you and explain that as you are aware repairs must be made from year to year to keep the buildings and equipment in order, so we must have the supplies to do them.

We say then that if the Department regard these requests in order, we would very sincerely approve of them. But there are certain articles that can be repaired and used for some time yet.

I would call to mind the fact that last year the Dept gave our school considerable assistance in making repairs, supplying paint. But as we said these things must be done from year to year, and we generally get very little in this item. We would like to ask, that if you don't approve, we would like to have new belts for our Bandola. Either a new washing machine, or the old one repaired, and we think that if we were to have a new one, we could get the old one repaired and install it with the new one and so speed up the work on wash days.

We have an ironer, but have never installed it on account of the danger of girls being left alone to work with it, and as the rollers are heated by gasoline we counted it rather a risk to let the girls use it. If belts are available, we will have it in use if we can obtain a promise that some of the staff will always supervise.

We would like to be frank in saying that there are many things we would have, many improvements we would like, but our school is not owned by the Indian Dept., as we often wish it was, and therefore we are receiving favors when we receive these considerations.

We thank you, sir, for all past favors, and are grateful in the trust that there is nothing that is practical and reasonable we could ask for, that you would refuse.

Yours obediently,

Sir,

At Reverend Principal Fuller's request I have made an inspection of the Shinawak House and find that some repairs are very necessary. Therefore I beg to enclose an estimate of the cost of material which would be required to put the building and equipment in good shape.

All interior walls require kalsomining and the woodwork throughout should have two coats of paint. A new hardwood floor is badly needed in the boys washroom. The treads on three stairways should be renewed as they are worn out, also roof of buildings require repairs.

Dear Sir:

Our School, the Shingwauk Home, is built with the main floor close to the ground, and the three furnaces are placed three feet below the ground. No basement, and always we have much trouble with water in the pits where the furnaces are located. During the past wet season these pits have been full of water, and no drain to carry it off. Other years we have bailed the water out, often having to do so every day.

Lately we decided to open a drain from where the land drops down to the river to the house. In doing this we discovered an old wood box drain rotted and filled in. We have opened this drain, and wish to lay it with tile drain pipe. This must be done at once as the excavating is done, and to assure you that this will be effectual in taking off the water, I can tell you that as soon as we had the drain open the water went out in a short time. The drain that we have opened will pass through our vegetable garden and will be beneficial in a double way.

The length of the drain is Five Hundred and Twenty Five Feet,

525 Feet of Drain Tile @ 77c per Ft. = $38.75.

Will you please ask the Indian Department if they would consider giving us this grant as it would mean much comfort to us in our work, and also make the building more healthy.

We shall ever be thankful.

Yours Faithfully,

G.H. Sims
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste Marie,
Ontario.

Dear Sir:

When I visited the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie on Wednesday last, the 24th inst., I found that, owing to the abnormally heavy rainfall which had prevailed in that part, the water had been seeping into the basement and furnace-room, and as the drain was choked, the Principal and the Farm Instructor with the aid of some of the bigger boys had undertaken the laborious task of digging out the drain to remove the obstruction. When I reached the school, they had actually dug a trench 259 yards long and at no spot less than 2 feet deep, while in other places nearer the school it was actually 5 feet in depth. They found that the box drain which had been installed was so badly rotted that it had caved in, and this caused the water to back up into the furnace-room.

I suggested to Mr. Fuller, the Principal, that no attempt should be made to repair the box drain, but that he should confer with the Indian Agent and agree with him to request your Department to provide 6 inch tile instead. I understood from Mr. Fuller that Mr. Indian Agent Sims agreed with the suggestion that the tile should replace the wooden drain, and I trust that any request which you may receive from him in this connection may receive your sympathetic consideration. I was unable to get a close estimate of the cost of the tile during my short stay in Sault Ste. Marie, but Mr. Fuller was of the opinion that it would not exceed $60, or $70.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

I have been instructed by our Commission to direct your attention to the heavy expenditure which they are obliged to make from year to year for bread at the Shingwauk Home, and to ask you to kindly give very careful consideration to the question of providing this School with facilities for baking bread. In support of this request I beg to state that the bills which were paid by our Commission for bread at this School during the year 1928, amounted to $2,117.10. Had the Commission purchased the flour required to meet the needs of the staff and pupils at their schedule rate of allowance which is 75 lbs. per head per quarter, the total cost of this flour would have amounted to $1,035.00 f.o.b. S.S. Ste. Marie, and they would thereby have effected a saving of $1,082.10.

As the average per capita cost of food at a number of our Society's other Schools where bread-baking facilities are provided, is only approximately $45.00 a year, while the average per capita cost of this same item at the Shingwauk Home is $62.00 a year, it is obvious that the lack of baking facilities is very largely responsible for the difference.

On various occasions during my visit to your Department, I have made known the wish of our Commission to have the baking facilities provided, not only in order that the operating expenses of the institution might be reduced, but that the pupils might benefit by this branch of education as well. On each occasion, a note was made of my request and sympathetic consideration of the situation promised. So far, however, no action has been taken, and our Commission has lost
heavily in consequence. They feel that the situation should not be allowed to continue as it is at present, and for this reason I shall be very grateful if you will go into the matter carefully, and provide this institution with the necessary baking facilities at the earliest date possible.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of May 1st and your reply to the same on May 7th (No. 13-0-5) re baking facilities for the Shingwauk Home, I beg to state that, I referred to the Principal the question of greater urgency with regard to the baking facilities and the root-house, and in his reply, he states that the baking facilities are undoubtedly the more urgent.

With regard to the question of accommodation for the installation of a bake oven, I beg to state that this is not available in the existing buildings. I discussed this matter fully with the Superintendent of Indian Education during his recent visit to Winnipeg, and as he knows the Shingwauk Home buildings very well, he agreed that any attempt to install a large bake-oven either in the Kitchen or in one end of the laundry, would not only prove unsatisfactory, but would seriously interfere with the work of those two departments. A small bake-house to serve until the new School is provided could be built on skids at a moderate cost, and I beg to recommend that this action be taken at an early date, and a suitable bake-oven, and mechanical dough-mixer installed. The dough-mixer could be operated by electric motor, as the Shingwauk Home derives its light and power from the light and power plant of the City of Sault Ste. Marie.

Commending this important matter to your favourable consideration, I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I made an examination of the Shingwauk Indian Home yesterday and find the sanitary conditions there rather unsatisfactory. MEMORANDUM:

November 13th, 1929.

I beg to report as follows in connection with certain other matters at the Shingwauk Home:

(1) Re:- Boys' bath tube not being connected with sewer. I found that there were three bath tubs in a small room off the boys' playroom but these are not connected with the sewer nor can water be run into them. (2) Re:- Bake House. Previous to leaving the school, Mr. Fuller erected a bake house. This is a small frame building with a cement floor. Mr. Hives does not consider it at all suitable for the purpose and, to use it for the purpose for which it is intended, it would be necessary to supply a coal burning bake oven - 100 loaf capacity.

I found that the school has previously purchased their bread from a bakery in the Soo at a cost of 11 cents a loaf and, as the expenditure for bread has appeared high to the M.S.C.C., Mr. Hives was advised that the M.S.C.C. considered that the bread should be baked at the school. I arranged with Mr. Hives to secure new prices for the supplying of the bread. Before leaving the Soo he informed me that he had an offer of bread at 8 cents a loaf and I immediately wrote the Secretary of the M.S.C.C. in connection with this offer and it will therefore not be necessary to make any arrangements for a bake oven until the Principal communicates further with the Department.

Mr. Hives also stated that a mangle and an ironer are necessary.

Dear Sir:

In conversation with Mr. Indian Agent Sims this morning, he informed me of the wishes of your Department in regard to the fixing up of the Principal's apartments at the Shingwauk Home. No doubt, since the visit of your representative, Mr. Thelen, you are well informed of the conditions that prevail there.

I beg to assure you sir, that all and any help received from the Department is deeply appreciated by us, and, speaking for myself, it has always been my aim to economise wherever it is possible to do so, when a sanction of expenditure has been given. For the same reason any request I have made of your Department has come after very careful consideration.

Your representative, Mr. Thelen, took back with him, after his visit to us, a note of many of our real needs. Amongst these was necessary repairs for the Principal's apartments. In relation to the lighting I note that one electric light fixture is allowed for the six rooms. May I here say that it is over thirty years since these rooms were last decorated. The papering and decorating was done by the man who is about to work on them now, so that he knows how long ago it is since the last work was done on them. There is nothing enticing or comfortable about them. There are just the bare cord drop light, one for each room. The wiring is faulty and unsafe. There is not one wall switch for any of the rooms, and no wall plugs for power or heat.

I had the electrician in yesterday to look over the place, and he informed me that it would cost £75.00 to put in proper decent fixtures and insure fair convenience and safety. I would be very grateful if the Department would kindly authorize Mr. Sims by wire that this work should be done.

In regard to your wishes relative to kitchen range, and the transferring of electrical range from
The main building to the Principal's apartments.

I may say that this range was a personal gift from a former lady worker of this school to the school, and therefore I have no right to transfer it. I may say however, that the coal burning range would cost $75.00, and that it would be almost necessary to have such a range in order to heat water for the bathroom. I sincerely hope therefore, that this may be forthcoming, and would appreciate it very much if you would kindly authorize the purchase of this range.

I recognize the fact that this building belongs to the Church, but even under the very best of conditions, we cannot do without your help, and certainly under the present deplorable conditions of decay and unsafety as exists here, your kindly help and consideration, of which I am familiar, is very vital to our existence. And moreover, the children we are trying to look after do really belong to the Department, and we, as workers are trying to give to them the very best we have.

Even after your Department has done all that I tried to point out to your representative should be done, things are still going to be very far behind. To speak frankly, this school, although in civilization, is fifty years behind, in many respects, the school at Lac la Ronge, which is two hundred miles away from the nearest town. I, and I can safely speak for my staff can endure hardship in the work if necessary, but I for one cannot live surrounded by carelessness and neglect that I see on every hand, and it is beyond the power that we have to improve matters very much. To me such living is a veritable waste of time and precious energy. Moreover, your children cannot possibly receive the care and attention they should have under such conditions.

At present the Staff are "doubling up" in order to give the Principal and family room. The cold weather is naturally nearby, and I would like to get settled down before Winter really sets in. It would therefore be a great relief to me if the Department would wire there sanction for attention to light and range as herein dealt with.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

We have been much inconvenienced of late by one of the furnaces being out of order. This furnace, which is supposed to heat the children's diningroom, staff rooms, Sr. classroom, boys' dormitory, was cracked last winter. So badly was one of the boiler sections fractured that water had to be added continually in order to give the required amount to the radiators. All through the summer it lay, although the late Principal knew of its condition all last winter. When I came this fall, I had to find it out for myself after trying to make a fire in the furnace. All through the winter so far, we have had to do without it, and I may say that this has been considered an exceptionally cold winter. The furnaces are of such ancient build, that they are obsolete, and we had to send the section away as a pattern to have one cast. Today it has arrived and so I hope that in the near future it will be rebuilt.

In regard to the Principal's apartments, I may say that the workmen are still at it, although they expect to be through next week. It has been a longer job than I had anticipated. The rooms were in a very filthy condition, and the paper had to be taken off, and in doing this, much of the plaster came along with it. It is, however, going to be very nice and I am very grateful to the Department for this improvement.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. F. Hewes,
Principal.

With reference to the attached memorandum I beg to say that as far as I know the only school contemplated during the coming summer is the new Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste Marie. The heating system designed for this building will be a low pressure system and the building will be erected by contract after being publicly advertised. The heating system is included in the general contract.

ARCHITECT.
January 12th, 1931.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Buskard -

If Parliament gives us the money we contemplate erecting only one new school in Ontario this summer that is the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie. The heating system is included in the general contract. It would be difficult for the Spencer Heater Company and the Dominion Stove Foundry Company to know who would be contracting on this work and I knew of no way in which we could help them. We might make a note of these firms and send them slips when the advertisement is being issued.

To Mr. Scott,

I beg to take the liberty of writing to you personally. I have been occupying a small building on the Shingwauk Home property for the past 16 years, paying a small rent to James Scott. In view of the faithful service I gave while Indian agent here, I respectfully ask if you would consider giving me a 10 year lease of this building. It needs a good deal of repair and I would undertake to make it comfortable providing the repairs would be considered as rent. The Shingwauk People does not use it for any purpose and the Principal informed me he would not have any objection to me occupying it for the summer months. He generally occupy it for the months of June, July, August and September which helps us both to...
Improve also health. I would undertake to be of no trouble to the Home folk.

I am thankful to tell you that I have been having very good health as I spent the past 3 winters in the lumber woods dealing, and I find outdoor life is what I require.

You may wonder at my age 80 next month that I ask for so long a lease but I am living in hopes of living a number of years yet.

In view of the pleasant relations between us in the past, I hope you will pay regard your very favorable consideration.

Have the honor to be Sir

I beg to report that on August 20th I proceeded to Sault Ste Marie to select a site for the new Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste Marie. On the evening of the 21st Mr. Simpson, M.P., arranged for a meeting with Mr. Wilkes, Architect of Sault Ste Marie, and I was able to obtain from him information necessary regarding local building conditions. The next morning in company with the Rev. Principal, Mr. Wilkes and Mr. Simpson I selected a suitable site for the new building. The site selected is approximately 200 feet to the rear of the existing building. It is on high land with good drainage and was satisfactory to all parties.

Mr. Simpson was anxious that local brick be used in the building and I visited the brick yard and inspected the brick and found same to be of good quality and have therefore specified the use of this brick in the building.

Mr. Wilkes is the only Architect in Sault Ste Marie and Mr. Simpson is anxious that he be appointed Inspector of Construction, and I would, therefore, recommend that if a contract is awarded for this building that he be appointed.

The plans and specifications are going out today together with the advertisement inviting tenders. The closing date is Sept. 15th.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the plans of the new Shingwauk Home, some of the contractors have inquired regarding the sewage disposal.

While Mr. Orr, your architect, was here looking over the prospective site, this matter was mentioned, and he favoured the septic tank system. At the present time the sewage empties into the river without going through any process such as septic tank.

I would certainly recommend that a proper septic tank system be established to handle this matter. Our pupils bathe in the river below where the sewage empties. That in itself is not good, and may cause serious health trouble sometime.

As there is no mention of this matter in the specifications, would you kindly let me know what system would be adopted, so that I may inform the contractors of this.

Dear Sir:

Would you kindly take up a matter with the Department in connection with the heating of our school. Of course, it is recognised by the Department that our heating system is very poor, and that the only real remedy is an entirely new system, but the Winter is coming on, and the present means of heating has to be patched up as well as we can do it. The two classrooms are heated by stove heaters. That is, they have the hot water radiators installed in them, but these insufficient to give the proper heat. The stove heater heretofore used are old, and in a dangerous condition, and require new ones. These will cost in the neighbourhood of not more than $70.00. The furnaces need new grates, and I estimate the cost of these installed would be $30.00.

I have been trying to fix up a room for a boy's readingroom. Some of our boys have to do study work in the evening, and they cannot do this in the playroom, and the classrooms are not convenient. We have quite a good room off the boy's playroom, and if it had proper heating installed, it would make a very good room for the boys. I can have a radiator taken from another part of the building where it is not really required. To do this would cost approximately $15.00.

Would you kindly take this matter up, so that if possible the work may be done as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find four accounts in duplicate, and duly certified correct. These accounts are all in connection with the building of the chicken house sanctioned by letters No. 15-C-12 of August 25th, and No. 15-C-5 of Sept. 15th.

I beg to say that I have been as careful as possible in buying the necessary material to do this work, and I may say that we have a very fine and up-to-date chicken house. It will hold 300 fowl. It is painted outside, and kalsomined inside. The floor is cement, and the walls are three ply of tongue and groove lumber taken from the Drill Hall, with building paper in between.

At present we have over 200 White Leghorn pullet in, and I assure you that I am very thankful for the building.

The carpenter will be through with his work of demolishing the Drill Hall, and carpenter work on the fish of this month.

Dear Sir:

I am anxious to get the pupils of our school interested in gardening this year, and would like to have twelve girls and twelve boys each caring for a plot of ground, and taking care of necessary tools that would be required for that purpose.

Two dozen garden rakes, hoes and watering cans would cost $56.00. I estimate seeds would cost $25.00.

I would also like to have a little competition in the caring for the plots, and if possible offer three prizes for girls and three for boys, and am wondering if the Department would like to put up two five dollar prizes.

Dear Sir:

The enclosed is a report given by the Grand Jury of the District of Algoma, and contains a reference to the Shingwauk Home. These gentlemen pay a quarterly visit of inspection, and generally they write their criticisms in the visitors' book, and we let it go at that. As they have given their report more publicity this time, I think it only right that I should comment on their statements.

The building is just about the same as it has always been, and compares very unfavorably alongside of other institutional buildings of the present day. Sanitary conditions are bad, and many other things about the place are bad. The roof is in a deplorable condition, and the rain leaks through in many parts of it on to the boys' beds. Paint is required, and the whole of the interior needs kalsomining. I have not made any request in this matter because our hopes of a new building seemed to be about to be realized. But if the actual building is to be postponed for any length of time, some improvements must be done.

In regard to sanitary conditions, I may say it is disgustingly bad. The Girls' toilets are directly off their playroom, and the smell is very often abominable. The boys' is worse as the closets are in very poor shape and are actually in the playroom.

I quite appreciate the fact that every effort is being made to curtail expenses, and I assure you sir, that we are willing to put up with anything within reason, providing the conditions do not drag along too far in the future.

I would be glad if you could give me a little encouragement in this respect. The work is prospering, and well worth all the efforts that are being made.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

DE. SHORT

Pursuant to instructions in your letter of the 4th instant, I have to report that, when in Sault Ste. Marie early this month, I made a very careful inspection of the Shingwauk Home. While the particular criticisms in the resolution of the local Kiwanis Club were founded in fact, the general conditions at this school are not quite so serious as those who are pressing for a new building would have us believe.

The interior of the building is so constructed, that there is no doubt a serious fire hazard. This hazard is increased by the inadequate heating units - 7 stoves in classrooms, playrooms, laundry, Principal's office, and Principal's residence and one-half dozen electric heaters in the staff bedrooms.

To put this old building, part of which was erected 57 years ago, in a safe condition, would be so expensive that it is not even a question. If school is to be conducted until a new building is provided, steps must be taken to minimize the risk of loss of life in the event of fire. Some months ago, we authorized the engagement of a night watchman who would constantly patrol the building. I find that the Rev. C. Hives, the Principal, has relied little too much on this employee. He has not sufficiently emphasized the fire drill and the fire escapes themselves.

We have been allowing $20 per month for the night watchman and the school has been giving him his board. I asked Mr. Hives if he was one hundred per cent satisfied that the man was on the job every minute of the night. He hesitated before replying that he was "reasonably sure". I asked him if we made the remuneration $75 a month if we could get a man on whom we could absolutely rely. He replied he could, and from the 16th instant, there has been on duty a night watchman who is thoroughly reliable.

With reference to the fire escapes themselves, I arranged for a guardrail on the boys' fire escape and instructed that a fire axe was to be always kept by the window opening thereon. The escape from the girls' dormitory was in bad condition, as reported by the Kiwanis Club Committee, and, on the 9th instant, I
arranged for two carpenters to come out to the school and I gave them instructions concerning a platform outside the window and a platform to the fire escape all properly surrounded by guardrails. Further, the ladder fire escape was raised so as to be easily reached, and was properly protected. The Kiwanis Committee reports concerning a straight ladder which lands on the peak of a pitch roof; but this is not a fire escape, as it leads only to the roof of the building.

To lessen the general risk, I instructed the carpenters to punch a door through an interior wall which divides the building on the dormitory floor. In the event of fire at one end of the building, the boys or the girls, as the case may be, could be moved to the other side to descend the fire escape or the interior staircase there.

The roof of the building is in rather poor condition and I authorized the carpenters to re-shingle those patches where there was any leaking.

The building accommodates 95 or 100 pupils without any real crowding, and I instructed the Principal to see that the number did not run over the 100 at any time. The boys' dormitory has plenty of air space and the girls' is not seriously crowded. In the past, the classrooms have been overcrowded; but I have instructed the Principal to adhere to the half-hour system, which will remedy this situation forthwith. The facilities and bath facilities are inadequate, but remedial measures need not be considered as the Department intends to discontinue the use of this building in the early future. The playrooms and the dining room have not been cared for as well as is desired, and I gave the Principal instructions regarding the ammunition. The matron at the school, Miss Battersby, is now practically wholly ill, and I intend to write to Dr. Westgate with a view to having her retired.

It should be remembered that this building is not a high structure and that there are no pupils more than 2½ feet from the ground. The dormitories are not locked at night and the windows to the fire escapes open easily. With your permission, I wish to instruct Mr. Indian Agent Sims to regularly inspect this school and to give particular attention to the safety of the children.

With your concurrence, I wish to authorize a few minor improvements, as follows:

1. Electric lights over the fire escapes.
2. Sheet iron and asbestos protection around the smoke pipes from stoves in kitchen and both playrooms.

- 3. Calomine and -
3. Calcimine and brushes for decorating the dormitories and a little paint to complete the henhouse.

4. Half screens for certain windows.

5. $150 for repairs to the farmer's cottage. The farm instructor, who is a good officer, has recently been married, and Mr. Hives wishes to give him one of the old stone houses to himself.

6. One horse to complete a second team for the school.

I may say that I was quite critical concerning the lack of cleanliness of certain parts of the old building and on the school grounds. Mr. Hives assures me that conditions are now much better than when he took it over, but he is going to take full advantage of the half-day system and have gangs of the younger children responsible daily for jobs that they can do. Mr. Hives does not know the department's wishes and is not going to treat them lightly, as I told him that we would close the school if the church authorities and himself felt that the difficulties and dangers were too great.

There are five buildings that should remain after the new main building is erected - the chapel, the farmer's residence, two summer cottages on the river and the new henhouse. The old hospital across the main road and all the other buildings, including the barn, should eventually be removed.

Russell T. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, June 30, 1931.

Sir:

I wish to confirm authority for certain improvements that were authorized at the Shingwauk Home by Mr. Ferrier upon his recent visit. You may engage two carpenters to fix the fire escapes, as directed by our officer; to patch the roof of the main building and to put a door in an interior wall on the dormitory floor. You may also arrange for the installation of electric lights over the fire escapes.

You should also provide protection near the smoke pipes from the stoves in the kitchen and in both playrooms. You may also provide salicinum and brushes for decorating the dormitories and a little paint to complete the henhouse. You may expend approximately $25 in providing half screens for certain windows in the school. You may also expend $150 for repairs to the farmer's cottage.

I note that the account for the horse, authorized by Mr. Ferrier, has already been presented and paid.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith, accounts in duplicate, from various firms, for material bought and work done at the Shingwauk Home as authorized by the Department.

The roof, which represents the largest expense, is now rain proof. New shingles replace old ones wherever required, and valleys and ridges have been renewed with flashing. It was also necessary to put up some eaves thoughing. The fire escape from the girl's dormitory has been properly built, and is now safe for use. The boys' fire escape has been repaired. Lights have been installed over each exit. A doorway from the girls' dormitory through the stone wall has been effected, and so giving access between the east and west parts of the building on the dormitory floor. Plumbing has been repaired wherever necessary, and enclosed is an account of same along with an account of plumbing done previous to Mr Ferrier's visit, but which he inspected and approved of.

All smoke pipes have been overhauled, and wherever necessary repaired. Also asbestos covered sheeting placed above smoke pipes. Some tinting has been done in the building, and we have enough Kalsomine to do what should be done this year.

I have not had the Farmer's house finished yet, for which a grant of $150.00 was made, but will do this before Winter.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

We are trying to carry out the instructions of the Department of Indian Affairs in respect to the half day system. In many respects it has been very difficult to do this. We have had to increase our staff, which has meant establishing a new department. Up to the present time the girls have done their sewing in the dining-room. This has been very inconvenient and unsatisfactory. Our new worker is taking up sewing classes with the girls, and must have an equipped sewing-room. The only room available for this department is a room on the top floor which is used as a clothing-room. This can be used if we can dispose of the clothing in a proper way, and I may say that this can be done, if we have clothing cupboards built. One hundred dollars will give us the necessary clothes cupboards. There are many empty spaces in the corridors and other places where cupboards can be built and used conveniently.

This is a very important matter, as I would like to work out the half-day system with success, and I feel sure it can be done if we have the room for accommodating the sewing classes.

Will you kindly place this matter before the Department at your earliest convenience, asking them to consider this matter, and if possible to allow us the necessary funds to build the cupboards.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I beg to place before you a request for the sanction of the Department to effect certain repairs that are urgently needed at our school.

Our Laundry machinery requires overhauling, and repaired. Last year, about this time, it was done, with the idea of making it last out until new equipment should come with the new building, which was to have been built last year. I estimate that if $30.00 is spent again on it this year, we can go through another year with it.

The chimney leading from the stove which heats the girls' playroom is in bad shape. On account of the chimney being so low, the smoke blows back into the girls' playroom anytime the wind blows. At one time there was an extension on the top of the chimney, but this blew off some years ago. The cost of renewing this would be $20.00.

The Department bought us a kitchen range two years ago. This now requires new grates, relining, and some new parts to the top. On account of having no proper heater for the Laundry irons, the kitchen range has to be used. Consequently the range is somewhat abused. It will cost approximately $25.00 to put the range in proper repair.

We have been having a great deal of trouble lately with our lights. Our building is very poorly lighted, and yet we have really more than the fuses can carry. Consequently the fuses are constantly blowing out, and of late the main fuse has been blowing, thereby throwing the whole building into darkness. You can well imagine the inconvenience as well as the possible danger it causes with so many children around. I have had an expert down, and of course he condemns the system as unsafe, as other have done before, but it could be made tolerably safe by dividing some of the circuits,
and lightening the load on the fuses. It would cost approximately $90.00 to do this.

Would you kindly place these matters before the Department for their best consideration. These repairs are not only necessary to maintain the proper standard in our administration, but also as a safeguard against possible danger.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. [signature]
Principal.

Gordon Sims Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

I am sorry to have to inform you that our hot water heating system in the boys' department has played out. It consists of a large cauldren or feed boiler. I tried to get it repaired, but it is too far gone. We must have another to take its place, as it is the only means we have of heating water for bathing the boys, and for scrubbing the boys' rooms.

Would you kindly place this matter before the Department and ask them if they would kindly supply us with another. The cost would be not over sixty dollars.

I may also say that the main water pipe into the Shingwauk Home has no shut-off. Some of the pipes are in very poor shape and liable to cause trouble, as they are leaking. I think it is very necessary that there should be a valve near the entrance of the water supply so that the water can be controlled if necessary. At the present time, it would have to be done in the city, over a mile away. The cost of installing this shut-off would be forty dollars.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

Will you place before the Department the necessity of having some renovation work and repair work done on the main building of the Shingwauk Home this year. There has been very little done in that respect for over two years, and for sanitary reasons as well as for looks there should be painting and tinting done this year. I may say that Shingwauk Home appears to be one of the sight listed on the Tourist's Guide, and a great many people passing through the locks come to see the Home during the Summer.

The building is old, and ready to be replaced, but until our hopes of a new building can be realized, we should keep this one in repair. There is a certain amount of plumbing to be done, and some of the floors are in bad shape. Windows and practically all wood work requires painting and all walls of main building require redecoration. The roof of the main building also requires repairing in places, and the roof of the laundry needs renewing.

After making a careful estimate, including expert labour required, I find it will cost approximately $575.00.

Will you please place this matter before the Department at your earliest convenience, so that we may get this work done before the Summer.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I have to place before you, for your consideration, a matter relating to repairs on Junior classroom which urgently requires attention. The recent heavy rains having shown up some leaky spots in the roof, and the plaster has fallen from the ceiling in consequence. Also in looking over the chimney which discharges from a stove in the classroom, I find that it is unsafe, and should be rebuilt. It is made of cement, and must have been in the first place, a very poor job. I may say that we have brick enough to build a proper one, but would require expert labour to do the work. After carefully estimating the cost of these necessary repairs, I think it can be done for not more than one hundred dollars. And I beg to assure you, that if the Department can sanction this work being done, I will see that the cost is brought as low as possible.

Will you kindly place this matter before the Department at an early date, so that the work may be done while the pupils are out of the classroom.

Yours faithfully,

An item of $50,000.00 was placed in the Estimates for 1930-1931 to commence the construction of a new building for the Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste Marie, Ontario. Owing to the necessity for rigid economy at the time, this item was afterwards disallowed.

The Superintendent of Indian Education inspected the school at that time and reported that owing to the age and condition of the building, repairs which would render it safe and satisfactory for occupation would be very costly, and for this reason only minor repairs, which were absolutely necessary, were made until such time as funds would be available for the erection of a new building.

Memorandum

Doctor McGill,

I beg to submit a report on an inspection of the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste Marie, made on the afternoon of November 1.

The north half of the Shingwauk Home was erected in 1874 as a school for boys. In 1880 a home for girls, called the Wawmash School was built about five miles south of the Shingwauk Home. The two schools were operated for about twelve years, when the Shingwauk Home was enlarged and the girls transferred there.

The outside walls of the building are constructed of local stone. The interior is entirely of frame construction and all of the floors are not on the same level, which necessitates going up and down steps while travelling from one room to another on the different floors. Originally the building was heated by stoves, but later a hot water heating system was installed, which consists of two hot water boilers. The heating boilers are installed in pits approximately five feet below the level of the basement floor. In the spring these pits are partly filled with water, as they are below the drainage system of the building.

The present building has outlived its usefulness and it would not be practical to remodel same. The interior layout was poorly planned, and in most cases access to one room is obtained by going through another. In fact it is very difficult to find one's way through the building without a guide.

The outside stone walls are in fair condition, but many cracks are developing, with a serious one in the laundry wing. All of the window sills are of wood, and they have deteriorated to such an extent that practically all the windows are out of plumb. The building itself is poorly located being on low ground at the bottom of a slope which leads to the rear of the building. In the spring the basement is necessarily badly flooded.

The fire escapes are so located that in case of fire it would be necessary for the children to pass from their dormitories through a hall at the top of the stair landing to reach them. In case of
fire the corridors and stair wells would rapidly fill with smoke, and under the present arrangement, it would be exceedingly difficult for the children to reach the fire escapes. I would recommend that a partition be erected at the head of the stairs on the dormitory floors, and a door provided to the stairs. This would be of some assistance in overcoming the above mentioned danger. The cost would be approximately $200.00.

In the laundry equipment there is an extractor. This extractor is being operated without a cover, and exposes those working in the laundry to unnecessary danger. This machine was manufactured by a firm that is no longer in existence, but I believe that arrangements could be made with the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. of Toronto to provide and install a suitable cover. The cover on these extractors is so arranged that when the lid is opened the power is automatically shut off.

The general location of the Shingwauk Home has many advantages. It is within the boundaries of the City of Sault Ste Marie, and therefore has the benefits of an adequate water supply, electric power and other advantages that the City enjoys. It is located one mile from the end of the street car line on a good road. This is of great benefit to the School as each year they have pupils attending the High School in Sault Ste Marie. At the present time there are ten.

I would recommend that when funds are available a new building be erected for the Shingwauk Home. It would be located approximately 300 feet to the rear of the present building on high ground, and the present building be demolished.

The Shingwauk Home and the land occupied are owned by the Diocese of Algoma. In 1930 plans were under way for the transfer of the property to the Department, but they were not completed. Before a new building can be erected it will be necessary to complete this transfer. The new School should have accommodation for 135 pupils. I may say that the Reverend Principal advises that approximately 70% of the pupils in attendance at this school are either orphans or children who have no homes.
I would like to refer to the very efficient way in which the Reverend Mr. Hives is carrying on his duties as Principal of this Institution. Everything in and outside the building presented a clean and neat appearance, and considering the many difficulties he has in operating a school in an old, poorly planned and dilapidated building such as the present Shingwauk Home, I think he deserves great credit. I saw many improvements since my last visit to the Shingwauk Home two years ago.

Dear Doctor McGill:

We have just come through one of the coldest snaps I have, so far, experience in Algoma, and I assure you I have no wish to have the experience repeated. At least not under existing conditions. It really seems impossible to keep any heat in this old building when the temperature gets as low as we have just recently had it.

With all the persistent and constant firing, until I was afraid of boilers bursting, we were unable to keep out the frost. On the night after Christmas day, a thirty foot two inch hot water pipe burst, we had to empty the system that heats up the girls' part of the building, and the plumbers were here until after midnight the next night repairing the damage, and cleaning up the mess. The next day two radiators in the classroom burst, and we had another system to empty, and repair.

Since Dec. 14th., we have burnt over twenty two tons of coal besides cords of wood and still we were cold. The heating system is quite inadequate to properly heat this building, and yet no other would be any better because there are innumerable cracks in the old walls, and the pipes seem to lie in such curious and dangerous places.

My hope is that the time is not far off when the good news of a new building is assured. May I wish you a very happy New Year, and success in your great work.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

Re Slate Blackboards

Until about a year ago practically all the slate blackboards put into Canadian schools came from Pennsylvania, and were uniformly good in quality. The high rate of exchange, sales tax and excise tax increased the cost of American slate to such an extent that slate blackboards from other sources entered this market, and to meet this competition considerable Pennsylvania slate of an inferior quality was supplied.

For the past twenty-five years we have supplied Canadian schools with "selected stock" slate blackboards under the name "Tunnel Brand". In order to maintain the high quality of this "Tunnel Brand" slate we recently secured Canadian distributional rights for blackboard slate from a certain European quarry, the quality and character of whose slate is recognized the world over. This slate combines those essential qualities of even texture, dark color, absence of all faults and a low calcium carbonate content insuring against fading and deterioration during years of use.

We are bringing these slate blackboards to the attention of the leading architects, some of whom have already had an opportunity of using them. One firm of architects who build a great many schools, and into one of whose schools these blackboards were installed this summer writes as follows:

"We will have no hesitancy in specifying these boards again and will be pleased to have an outline from you as to just what quality and manufacture of slate this is, so that we can incorporate it in our specifications in the future".

Should you care to examine a sample of this slate we will be glad to send same, and also to have you suggest to your contractors that they ask us for prices.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Thanks for your letter of the 28th in which you say you will consider the matter of using White Pine in the proposed new Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

We have also received a copy of your reply to the Crane Lumber Company of Thessalon in which you state that the interior finish is to be of Douglas Fir.

For strength, such as timbers, Douglas Fir is without doubt the strongest Canadian wood but, for panelling or decorative purposes, Canadian White Pine (Pinus Strobua) is, we believe supreme. In the first place, it does not shrink, swell or warp as much as other woods do and, when it is put up, it stays put. Also, it does not have to be veneered but the panelling can be erected right on the job.

Under separate cover, we are mailing you a book we recently published and, on pages 14, 15, 16 and 17, you will find some rather good photographic reproductions of White Pine panelling and interior work.
